Title: Midson v. Meeting House Lane Medical Practice, P.C.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Generally, piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: HEALTH  Malpractice. Physician who became patient's attending physician after diagnosis and beginning treatment was not liable for medical malpractice.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: FDJ, LLC v. Determan
Court: Supreme Court of South Dakota.
Headnote: There are six factors to consider when determining whether equity demands a disregard of the corporate entity: (1) undercapitalization; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) absence of corporate records; (4) payment by the corporation of individual obligations; (5) fraudulent misrepresentation by corporate directors; and (6) use of the corporation to promote fraud, injustice or illegality.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Individual members of LLC were not jointly and severally liable for LLC's breach of purchase agreement with business owner.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Timilon Corporation v. Empowerment Justice Center Corporation
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Under Maryland law, a party may seek to pierce the corporate veil when necessary to prevent fraud or enforce a paramount equity.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Judgment. Entry of default judgment was proper in seller's action against entities and their operators alleging failure to pay for air purifiers.

Title: Keyes v. Weller
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: Two oft-invoked common-law veil-piercing theories are (1) alter ego, which is triggered when there is such unity between corporation and individual that the separateness of the corporation has ceased, and (2) when the corporate form is used as a sham to perpetrate a fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Officers and Directors. Statute limiting liability of corporate agents had no effect on common-law fraud claims against agents for their own tortious conduct.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Kwok
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, alter ego or piercing the corporate veil has two elements: (1) the corporate entity whose form is to be disregarded is so dominated and controlled by its alleged alter ego that the corporate entity and its alter ego are, in fact, a single economic unit, and (2) the corporate form to be disregarded causes fraud or some similar injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Chapter 11 bankruptcy trustee had standing to bring turnover claim on behalf of creditors at large.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Kwok
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, when considering on a alter ego or veil piercing claim whether corporate form causes fraud or similar injustice or fraudulent intent in the creation of the corporate form – it is only necessary to establish that the corporate form causes fraud or a similar injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Chapter 11 bankruptcy trustee had standing to bring turnover claim on behalf of creditors at large.

Title: Murphy v. Jewell
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: While the decision whether to pierce the corporate veil in a given instance will necessarily depend on the attendant facts and equities, piercing the corporate veil generally requires a showing that: (1) the owner exercised complete domination of the corporation or limited liability corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil which resulted in that party's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Plaintiffs stated claim for piercing corporate veil against sole shareholder who allegedly wound down company following accident to be judgment proof.

Title: Louis Monteleone Fibres, Ltd. v. Hudson Baylor Brookhaven, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: While decision whether to pierce the corporate veil in a given instance will necessarily depend on the attendant facts and equities, generally, piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation or limited liability company (LLC) in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil which resulted in the party's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Waste-paper broker sufficiently alleged facts to support claim to pierce corporate veil of LLCs to hold its members personally liable.

Title: In re DuMouchelle
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, piercing a corporate veil is an equitable remedy that should only be invoked in instances of fraud, illegality, or injustice.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. Gem flipper fraudulently induced transfer of funds to his LLC through false pretenses, not larceny, and thus voidable title passed to LLC under Michigan law.

Title: W.P. Productions, Inc. v. Tramontina U.S.A., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Florida law for piercing the corporate veil, which requires the corporate form to have been used fraudulently or for an improper purpose, "improper purposes" can include a subterfuge to mislead or defraud creditors, to hide assets, or to evade the requirements of a statute, or some analogous betrayal of trust.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporation's sole shareholder used corporate form for improper purpose of evading Florida's Rule of Priorities, supporting piercing of corporate veil.

Title: W.P. Productions, Inc. v. Tramontina U.S.A., Inc.

Headnote: Under Florida law, piercing the corporate veil is appropriate when the corporate form was used fraudulently or for an improper purpose.

Title: Dragons 516 Limited v. Knights Genesis Investment Limited

Headnote: Generally, piercing the corporate veil to reach the owners of a corporation requires a showing that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff.

Title: JNM Express, LLC v. Lozano
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: The "injustice" prong of the alter ego basis for piercing the corporate veil references the kinds of abuse that the corporate structure should not shield, like fraud, evasion of existing obligations, circumvention of statutes, monopolization, criminal conduct, and the like; such abuse is necessary before disregarding the existence of a corporation as a separate entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Injustice prong for piercing corporate veil on alter ego theory was not met in truck driver's personal injury action against trucking companies.

Title: Ene v. Graham
Court: Supreme Court of Nevada.
Headnote: Under-capitalization, where it is clearly shown, is an important factor in determining whether the doctrine of alter ego should be applied; absent fraud or injustice, however, it is not an absolute ground for disregarding a corporate entity.

Title: Board of Managers of Brighton Tower II Condominium v. Brighton Builder, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Generally, a plaintiff seeking to pierce the corporate veil must show that (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Webb v. Medicalodges, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Missouri, Western Division.
Headnote: Under Missouri law as to alter ego liability, corporate forms will be ignored and the corporate veil pierced only if three factors are shown: (1) control, which is not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own, (2) such control must have been used by the corporation to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) the control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Estate of skilled nursing facility resident put forth sufficient allegations to pierce the corporate veil of corporation which operated facility.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: ChampionX, LLC v. Resonance Systems, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Tennessee.
Headnote: Under Tennessee law, piercing the corporate veil is an equitable doctrine applied in extreme circumstances to prevent the use of a corporate entity to defraud or perform illegal acts.

Title: Boulder Falcon, LLC v. Brown
Court: United States District Court, D. Utah.
Headnote: Under Utah law, nonexhaustive factors to be considered in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil are: (1) undercapitalization of a one-man corporation; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) nonpayment of dividends; (4) siphoning of corporate funds by the dominant stockholder; (5) nonfunctioning of other officers or directors; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) the use of the corporation as a facade for operations of the dominant stockholder or stockholders; and (8) the use of the corporate entity in promoting injustice or fraud.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Genuine disputes of material fact precluded summary judgment in favor of defendants on LLC's claim for breach of contract under Georgia law.

Title: In re Ward
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Georgia, Valdosta Division.
Headnote: Under Georgia law, protection of corporate veil can be set aside if court finds that individual shareholder has used corporate form to defeat justice, perpetuate fraud, promote crime, evade contractual or tort responsibility, or for any other reason which in equity or good conscience would justify disregard of corporate entity.

Title: Citibank, N.A. v. Aralpa Holdings Limited Partnership
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, the requirement for piercing the corporate veil that a shareholder used the corporation to commit a fraud or wrong against plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury can be satisfied either by showing outright fraud, or another type of wrong, such as a breach of a legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; the law requires only that the shareholder's wrongdoing resulted in the plaintiff's injury, not that the injuries suffered by the plaintiff were caused by the shareholder's wrongful conduct to the exclusion of all other possible influences.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Guarantor exercised domination over LLCs such that they had become a mere instrumentality of him, as required to reverse-pierce their corporate veils.

Title: Citibank, N.A. v. Aralpa Holdings Limited Partnership
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, relevant inquiry to reverse-pierce the corporate veil is not whether a corporation was formed to commit a fraud or wrong, but whether a corporation was used to commit a fraud or wrong.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Guarantor exercised domination over LLCs such that they had become a mere instrumentality of him, as required to reverse-pierce their corporate veils.

Title: Doheny v. International Business Machines, Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil under New York law, a plaintiff must show that (1) the controlling entity exercised complete domination over the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue, and (2) such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce the veil.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Discrimination. Former employee alleged that employer would not have laid her off but for her age, as required to state disparate-treatment claim under ADEA.

Title: Palmtag v. Republican Party of Nebraska
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: A court will disregard a corporation's identity only where the corporation has been used to commit fraud, violate a legal duty, or perpetrate a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of the rights of another.

Title: Mattingly v. R.J. Corman Railroad Group, LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Kentucky law, two elements must be met in order to pierce corporate veil: (1) domination of corporation resulting in loss of corporate separateness and (2) circumstances under which continued recognition of corporation would sanction fraud or promote injustice.

Title: Coast-to-Coast Produce, LLC v. Lakeside Produce USA, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, in considering element of piercing the corporate veil, that the corporate entity was used to commit a fraud or wrong, it is not necessary to prove that the owner caused the entity to directly harm the complainant; it is sufficient that the owner exercised his or her control over the entity in such a manner as to wrong the complainant.

Title: Taie v. Ten Bridges LLC
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Washington, at Seattle.
Headnote: Under Washington law, for the first element of the "alter ego" theory of corporate liability to be met, the court must find an abuse of the corporate form, which typically involves fraud, misrepresentation, or some form of manipulation of the corporation to the stockholder's benefit and creditor's detriment.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Mortgages and Deeds of Trust. Unjust enrichment barred purchaser of surplus foreclosure-sale proceeds from retaining funds obtained through its equity-stripping scheme.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Scarborough v. LaRocca
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: A member of a limited-liability company (LLC) or a corporation who practices fraud upon a third party or breaches any professional duty or commits any other negligent or wrongful act may be found liable for the debts, obligations, or liabilities of the LLC or corporation; in that instance, a court can pierce the corporate veil in order to reach the alter ego of the corporate member and hold the corporate member liable for the debts of the corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Allegations of solidary liability between LLC member and LLC barred dismissing, as prescribed, former employee's unpaid-wage claims against member.

Title: Groth v. Ferrante
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Concept of piercing corporate veil is exception to general rule that corporation exists independently of its owners, who are not personally liable for its obligations, and who may incorporate for express purpose of limiting their liability, which exception courts will invoke only where necessary to prevent fraud or to achieve equity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil of judgment debtor to reach shareholders was not warranted in judgment creditors' action seeking to enforce default judgment.

Title: Groth v. Ferrante
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Generally, plaintiff seeking to pierce corporate veil must show that (1) owners exercised complete domination of corporation with respect to challenged transaction, and (2) that domination was used to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiff which resulted in injury to plaintiff; in addition to complete domination of corporation, pleading must allege abuse of privilege of doing business in corporate form to perpetrate wrong or injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil of judgment debtor to reach shareholders was not warranted in judgment creditors' action seeking to enforce default judgment.

Title: Paul v. Bathurst

Headnote: There are six factors to consider when determining whether equity demands a disregard of the corporate entity: (1) undercapitalization; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) absence of corporate records; (4) payment by the corporation of individual obligations; (5) fraudulent misrepresentation by corporate directors; and (6) use of the corporation to promote fraud, injustice or illegality.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Paul v. Bathurst
Court: Supreme Court of South Dakota.
Headnote: The six factors to consider when determining whether to pierce the corporate veil can be grouped into two separate prongs: the "separate corporate identity" prong and the "fraud or inequitable consequences" prong; if the four factors under the "separate corporate identity" prong are present in sufficient number and/or degree, then the court will consider the two factors under the "fraud or inequitable consequences" prong.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Independent Contractors. Whether ranch manager was an employee or independent contractor, for statute of limitation purposes, could not be resolved on motion to dismiss.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Francisco A. Mateo MD, Inc. v. Proia
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Seventh District, Mahoning County.
Headnote: A judgment on a specific fraud claim is not required to satisfy the second element of the piercing of the corporate veil test, which requires a showing that control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity.
Document Preview: TORTS  Conversion. Partner had an interest in partnership funds with constructive possession or right to possession, as required for claim for conversion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Francisco A. Mateo MD, Inc. v. Proia
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Seventh District, Mahoning County.
Headnote: The second element of the piercing the corporate veil test, which requires a showing that control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, does not only encompass fraud or illegal acts, but also includes a catch-all category of similarly unlawful acts applicable where other egregious conduct is committed by the defendant using their enmeshed control over the entity and where the conduct causes unjust loss to the piercing party.
Document Preview: TORTS  Conversion. Partner had an interest in partnership funds with constructive possession or right to possession, as required for claim for conversion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Doherty v. Town of Woodstock
Court: Supreme Court of Vermont.
Headnote: The court will look beyond the corporation to its shareholders for liability, that is, pierce the corporate veil, where the corporate form has been used to perpetrate a fraud, and also where the needs of justice dictate. 11A Vt. Stat. Ann. § 6.22(b).

Title: Liberty Aviation Museum, Inc. v. JRM Marine Consulting, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Sixth District, Ottawa County.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, a plaintiff must show that (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.

Title: 138-77 Queens Blvd LLC v. Silver

Title: In re Nilhan Financial, LLC

Headnote: Under Florida law, to successfully pierce the corporate veil, claimant must prove that: (1) corporation is mere instrumentality of shareholder, i.e., shareholder dominated and controlled the corporation to such an extent that it did not have an independent existence and shareholder was in fact an alter ego of the corporation; (2) shareholder engaged in improper conduct, i.e., the corporate form was used fraudulently or for an improper purpose; and (3) the fraudulent or improper use of the corporate form caused injury to claimant.

Title: Deutsche Bank AG v. Sebastian Holdings, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, corporate veils exist for a reason and should be pierced only reluctantly and cautiously; because the law permits the incorporation of businesses for the very purpose of isolating liabilities among separate entities, the corporate veil is pierced only under exceptional circumstances, for example, when the corporation is a mere shell, serving no legitimate purpose, and used primarily as an intermediary to perpetuate fraud or to promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Equitable factors rendered harmless any error in application of Turks and Caicos law to bank's claim for piercing judgment debtor's corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Deutsche Bank AG v. Sebastian Holdings, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, the improper use of the corporate form is the key to the inquiry into whether a corporate veil should be pierced, as it is true that courts will disregard legal fictions, including that of a separate corporate entity, when they are used for fraudulent or illegal purposes; unless something of the kind is proven, however, to do so is to act in opposition to the public policy of the state as expressed in legislation concerning the formation and regulation of corporations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Equitable factors rendered harmless any error in application of Turks and Caicos law to bank's claim for piercing judgment debtor's corporate veil.

Title: Deutsche Bank AG v. Sebastian Holdings, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: In Connecticut, New York, and the Turks and Caicos Islands (TCI), piercing the corporate veil is an extraordinary remedy that requires, at a minimum, a determination by the court that the corporate form was used to promote a wrong or injustice, and that a fundamental unfairness would result from a failure to disregard the corporate form; in none of these jurisdictions is it sufficient only to show that the defendant exercised complete domination and control over the corporation or commingled assets, as the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must also show that the corporate form was a mere shell used primarily as an intermediary to perpetrate fraud or to promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Equitable factors rendered harmless any error in application of Turks and Caicos law to bank's claim for piercing judgment debtor's corporate veil.

Title: Arnold v. LME, Inc.

Headnote: The second prong of the two-prong test for determining whether to pierce the corporate veil from Minn. Laborers Health & Welfare Fund v. Scanlan, 360 F.3d 925, under which the court considers if adherence to the corporate fiction would sanction a fraud, promote injustice, or lead to an evasion of legal obligations, looks for causation and culpability.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Nature and control of owner-operated corporation weighed against piercing the corporate veil, in former employees' action against corporate owners.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Arnold v. LME, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: A corporation's inability to pay its debt alone is not sufficient to support a finding of injustice under the second prong of the two-prong test for determining whether to pierce the corporate veil from Minn. Laborers Health & Welfare Fund v. Scanlan, 360 F.3d 925, under which the court considers if adherence to the corporate fiction would sanction a fraud, promote injustice, or lead to an evasion of legal obligations; rather, it is only when the shareholders disregard the separateness of the corporate identity and when that act of disregard causes the injustice or inequity or constitutes the fraud that the corporate veil may be pierced.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Nature and control of owner-operated corporation weighed against piercing the corporate veil, in former employees' action against corporate owners.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: AHBP LLC v. Lynd Company
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Texas, San Antonio Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, claims to pierce the corporate veil fall into three categories: (1) the corporation is the alter ego of its owners and/or shareholders, (2) the corporation is used for illegal purposes, and (3) the corporation is used as a sham to perpetrate a fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Exclusive licensee adequately alleged that licensor was founding company's alter ego so that corporate veil could be pierced for contract claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Grayiel v. AIO Holdings, LLC
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Kentucky, Louisville Division.
Headnote: In analyzing whether to pierce the corporate veil under Kentucky law, there are two dispositive elements: (1) domination of the corporation resulting in a loss of corporate separateness, and (2) circumstances under which continued recognition of the corporation would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. Lender was liable for aiding and abetting tortious conduct, related to scheme to defraud creditors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Etage Real Estate LLC v. Stern
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: The elements of veil piercing are that (1) the owners exercised complete domination and control of the corporation with respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff, resulting in the plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment creditor was not entitled to summary judgment on veil-piercing claim against 50% owners of nonparty judgment debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: DePetris v. Traina
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: While the decision whether to pierce the corporate veil in a given instance will necessarily depend on the attendant facts and equities, generally, piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation (or limited liability company (LLC)) in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil which resulted in the party's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing the corporate veil was not warranted to hold sole member of LLC responsible for judgment against LLC in underlying personal injury lawsuit.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: DePetris v. Traina
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: In determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, evidence of domination of the corporation by its owners in respect to the transaction attacked, alone, does not suffice without an additional showing that it led to inequity, fraud or malfeasance.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing the corporate veil was not warranted to hold sole member of LLC responsible for judgment against LLC in underlying personal injury lawsuit.

Title: Chester Green Estates, LLC v. Arlington Chester, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Generally, a plaintiff seeking to pierce the corporate veil must show that (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation with respect to the challenged transaction, and (2) that domination was used to commit fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in injury to the plaintiff.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Vendor and Purchaser. New owner of real property was bona fide purchaser for value where notice of pendency related to prior purchase agreement had been cancelled.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re All Year Holdings Limited
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, a court may pierce the corporate veil where (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Estate of parent LLC succeeded to LLC's membership in special-purpose vehicle LLC, so automatic dissolution was not triggered for lack of members.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Pierre Investments, Inc. v. CLS Capital Group, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Sixth District, Lucas County.
Headnote: The corporate form may be disregarded and individual shareholders held liable for corporate misdeeds when: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity; and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Parties. Broker that dissolved before it entered loan agreement that was subject of borrower's breach-of-contract action was not entity capable of being sued.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Securities Investor Protection Corporation v. Bernard L. Madoff Investment Securities LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Federal common law allows piercing of the corporate veil where (1) a corporation uses its alter-ego status to perpetrate a fraud or (2) where it so dominates and disregards its alter-ego's corporate form that the alter-ego was actually carrying on the controlling corporation's business instead of its own.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Jurisdiction. Contacts of foreign entities and persons with New York were not random, isolated, or fortuitous even if their conduct took place outside of forum.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Malaro v. Wilkie
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, two circumstances justify piercing the corporate veil: the first is when the subject party exercises pervasive control of the activities of the corporation and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of the intercorporate relationship, and the second is when there is a confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of the separate nature of the corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about the manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Fact that contractor was president and sole officer of corporation did not constitute pervasive control in support of piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Malaro v. Wilkie
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Massachusetts courts consider 12 factors to guide their veil-piercing analysis, including: (1) common ownership; (2) pervasive control; (3) confused intermingling of business assets; (4) thin capitalization; (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) no payment of dividends; (8) insolvency at time of litigated transaction; (9) siphoning away of corporation's funds by dominant shareholder; (10) nonfunctioning of officers and directors; (11) use of corporation for transactions of dominant shareholders; and (12) use of corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Fact that contractor was president and sole officer of corporation did not constitute pervasive control in support of piercing corporate veil.

Headnote: Plaintiff seeking to pierce the corporate veil generally must show that (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.

Headnote: Evidence of individuals' domination of a corporation, alone, does not suffice to pierce the corporate veil without an additional showing that it led to inequity, fraud, or malfeasance.

Title: In re Contempt of Pavlos-Hackney
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan.
Headnote: Courts will disregard the separate existence of corporate entities when it is used to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, protect fraud, or defend crime.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Contempt. Contempt orders against business that operated restaurant and its owner after court orders to cease operation of restaurant were civil in nature.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Hill International, Inc. v. JTS Realty Corporation
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: The court may pierce the corporate veil under two exceptional circumstances: the first is where the shareholders, acting through the corporation, commit fraud or deceit on a third party such that justice demands the corporate veil be pierced; in the second instance, the shareholders disregard the corporate formalities to such an extent that the shareholders and the corporation become indistinguishable, i.e., the corporation was operated as the alter ego of the shareholder.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Joint Ventures. Sufficient evidence supported trial court's finding that real estate corporation was operating in single business enterprise with property developer.

Title: Hill International, Inc. v. JTS Realty Corporation
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Where fraud or deceit is absent, other circumstances must be so strong as to clearly indicate that the corporation and shareholder operated as one in order to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Joint Ventures. Sufficient evidence supported trial court's finding that real estate corporation was operating in single business enterprise with property developer.

Title: Liberty Highrise Pvt. Ltd. v. Praxis Energy Agents DMCC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.

Title: Liberty Highrise Pvt. Ltd. v. Praxis Energy Agents DMCC

Title: Liberty Highrise Pvt. Ltd. v. Praxis Energy Agents DMCC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Court must consider common characteristics broadly utilized by reviewing courts in deciding whether to find an individual to be an alter ego of a corporate entity and disregard corporate form, and must keep in mind that, in each case in which reviewing courts have disregarded the corporate form, evidence demonstrated an abuse of that form through ongoing fraudulent activities of a principal, or a pronounced and intimate commingling of identities of the corporation and its principal.

Title: In re Wolf
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Although, under Illinois law, a corporation is a legal entity separate and distinct from its shareholders, directors, and officers, this separate and distinct legal entity will be disregarded, and the corporate veil pierced, where observance of the fiction of separate identities would sanction a fraud or promote injustice under the circumstances.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Court properly granted Chapter 7 trustee's claim for outside reverse veil-piercing, so as to use corporate assets to satisfy debtor's personal debts.

Title: Unruh Turner Burke and Frees, PC v. Tattersall Development Company

Title: Partner Reinsurance Company Ltd. v. RPM Mortgage, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil and hold owners liable for corporate wrongdoing under Delaware law, a plaintiff must show an overall element of injustice or unfairness; to show this, a plaintiff need not prove that there was actual fraud, nor must it prove the corporation was created with fraud or unfairness in mind.

Title: Partner Reinsurance Company Ltd. v. RPM Mortgage, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil and hold owners liable for corporate wrongdoing under Delaware law, the corporate structure itself must have been used to further the fraud or injustice or as a shield for unjust acts; in other words, courts look behind the corporate curtain generally where the facts indicate the corporate entity has been or is being used by those in control of it to perpetrate a fraud or to promote injustice.

Title: Philip Morris USA, Inc. v. Rintoul
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, litigants must prove three factors by a preponderance of the evidence: (1) the shareholder dominated and controlled the corporation to such extent that the corporation's independent existence was in fact nonexistent and the shareholder was in fact an alter ego of the corporation; (2) the corporate form must have been used fraudulently or for an improper purpose; and (3) the fraudulent or improper use of the corporate form caused injury to the claimant.
Document Preview: GLBT  Torts. Husband could not recover loss-of-consortium damages for premarital injury to smoker, notwithstanding unconstitutionality of same-sex marriage ban.

Title: In re Flint Water Cases
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, in considering whether an entity is a mere instrumentality of another, in order to pierce the corporate veil, factors to be evaluated include: (1) whether the corporation is undercapitalized, (2) whether separate books are kept, (3) whether there are separate finances for the corporation, (4) whether the corporation is used for fraud or illegality, (5) whether the corporate formalities have been followed, and (6) whether the corporation is a sham.

Title: Martin v. Top Quality Professional Construction, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: To determine whether party seeking to pierce corporate veil has met its burden, courts consider whether party has presented evidence demonstrating: (1) under capitalization; (2) absence of corporate records; (3) fraudulent representation by corporation shareholders or directors; (4) use of corporation to promote fraud, injustice, or illegal activities; (5) payment by corporation of individual obligations; (6) commingling of assets and affairs; (7) failure to observe required corporate formalities; or (8) other shareholder acts or conduct ignoring, controlling, or manipulating corporate form.

Title: Jinks v. Credico (USA) LLC
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Suffolk.
Headnote: To trigger veil-piercing liability, a plaintiff must show the following factors: (1) common ownership; (2) pervasive control; (3) confused intermingling of business assets; (4) thin capitalization; (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) no payment of dividends; (8) insolvency at the time of the litigated transaction; (9) siphoning away of corporation's funds by dominant shareholder; (10) nonfunctioning of officers and directors; (11) use of the corporation for transactions of the dominant shareholders; and (12) use of the corporation in promoting fraud.

Title: Mohegan Lake Motors, Inc. v. Maoli

Headnote: Under New York law, piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Fact issue as to whether it was appropriate to pierce corporate veil of car dealership's buyer LLC precluded summary judgment on seller LLC's claims.

Title: Mohegan Lake Motors, Inc. v. Maoli
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, corporate veil piercing is warranted when the corporate form is abused either through on-going fraudulent activities of a principal, or a pronounced and intimate commingling of identities of the corporation and its principal or principals.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Fact issue as to whether it was appropriate to pierce corporate veil of car dealership's buyer LLC precluded summary judgment on seller LLC's claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Mohegan Lake Motors, Inc. v. Maoli
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil under New York law, a plaintiff must allege more than the underlying fraud or breach of contract in the sense that in addition to the fraud or breach of contract or other injustice he or she must also allege that the corporate structure itself was used to further the fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Fact issue as to whether it was appropriate to pierce corporate veil of car dealership's buyer LLC precluded summary judgment on seller LLC's claims.

Title: Childs v. Pommer
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, a plaintiff must show fraud in asserting the corporate existence or must show that recognition of the corporate existence will result in injustice or inequitable consequences.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing construction company's corporate veil as a limited-liability company (LLC) was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Ledford v. Keen
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Texas law's veil-piercing doctrine applies in various scenarios, including when the corporate fiction is used as a means of perpetrating fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Under Texas law, as predicted by Court of Appeals, corporate veil could not be pierced based solely on evidence of undercapitalization.

Title: Ledford v. Keen
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, only "constructive fraud" is required to support piercing of corporate veil, meaning the breach of some legal or equitable duty which, irrespective of moral guilt, the law declares fraudulent because of its tendency to deceive others, to violate confidence, or to injure public interests.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Under Texas law, as predicted by Court of Appeals, corporate veil could not be pierced based solely on evidence of undercapitalization.

Title: Ledford v. Keen
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, neither fraud nor an intent to defraud need be shown to allow piercing of corporate veil, only that recognizing the separate corporate existence would bring about an inequitable result.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Under Texas law, as predicted by Court of Appeals, corporate veil could not be pierced based solely on evidence of undercapitalization.

Title: In re Patel
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Orlando Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, alter ego claim is action to impose liability on corporation's principals or related entities where corporation was organized or used to mislead creditors or to perpetrate fraud upon them.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Under Florida law, limited liability company (LLC) owned by debtor's daughter, that acquired and operated hotel, was not debtor's nominee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Patel
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Orlando Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, when appropriate, courts will pierce corporate veil upon finding by preponderance of evidence that (1) shareholder dominated and controlled corporation to such extent that corporation's existence, was in fact nonexistent and shareholders were in fact alter egos of corporation; (2) corporate form must have been used fraudulently or for improper purpose; and (3) fraudulent or improper use of corporate form caused injury to claimant.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Under Florida law, limited liability company (LLC) owned by debtor's daughter, that acquired and operated hotel, was not debtor's nominee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Mortimer v. McCool
Court: Supreme Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Corporate veil will be pierced and the corporate form disregarded whenever justice or public policy demand, such as when the corporate form has been used to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, protect fraud, or defend crime.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Enterprise liability doctrine did not apply to permit judgment creditor to pierce veil of judgment debtor LLC's affiliated corporate entity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Mortimer v. McCool
Court: Supreme Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: The following factors are relevant to the inquiry whether to pierce the corporate veil: undercapitalization, failure to adhere to corporate formalities, substantial intermingling of corporate and personal affairs, and use of the corporate form to perpetrate a fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Enterprise liability doctrine did not apply to permit judgment creditor to pierce veil of judgment debtor LLC's affiliated corporate entity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Hunter v. Shield
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: The test in Ohio for whether a court can pierce the corporate veil is whether: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud, an illegal act, or a similarly unlawful act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Sales. Contract for sale and installation of a ceramic home coating product was predominately a contract for sale of goods under the UCC.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Blackwell v. Superior Safe Rooms LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Courts may invoke equitable doctrine of piercing corporate veil in order to protect innocent third parties from fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment debtor's corporate form was so ignored, controlled, or manipulated that it was merely the instrumentality of garnishee defendants.

Title: Blackwell v. Superior Safe Rooms LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: In order to disregard the corporate form of an entity, the fraud or injustice alleged by a party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must be caused by, or result from, misuse of the corporate form.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment debtor's corporate form was so ignored, controlled, or manipulated that it was merely the instrumentality of garnishee defendants.

Title: Shorter Brothers, Inc. v. Vectus 3, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil is not a power that is lightly exercised; it may be appropriate when the corporate entity is (1) undercapitalized, (2) formed or operated with a fraudulent purpose, or (3) operated as an instrumentality or alter ego of its shareholders.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was warranted so as to hold corporation's individual owners personally liable for breach of sales contract.

Title: Palmerone v. Staples
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Broadly speaking, the courts will disregard the corporate form, or, to use accepted terminology, pierce the corporate veil, whenever necessary to prevent fraud or to achieve equity.

Title: Segal v. Forastero, Inc.

Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, the aggrieved creditor must show its injury was caused by the use of the corporation to mislead creditors or to perpetrate a fraud upon them.

Title: Five Solas, LLC v. Ram Realty Services, LLC
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: Sole ownership interest of a corporate entity does not entitle a claimant to pierce the corporate veil, absent some fraudulent purpose or conduct.

Title: Manichaean Capital, LLC v. Exela Technologies, Inc.
Court: Court of Chancery of Delaware.
Headnote: Acts intended to leave a debtor judgment proof are sufficient to show fraud and injustice, as required to disregard the corporate form and pierce the corporate veil.

Title: BIC Corporation v. Chicago Import, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In order to show circumstances indicating that adherence to fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction fraud or promote injustice, for the purpose of piercing the corporate veil, a plaintiff need not establish actual fraud, but rather the less rigid standard of fraud, injustice, or the like.

Title: DeJesus v. R.P.M. Enterprises, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Ordinarily the corporate veil is pierced only under exceptional circumstances, for example, where the corporation is a mere shell, serving no legitimate purpose, and used primarily as an intermediary to perpetuate fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Workers' Compensation. Workers' compensation commissioner lacked jurisdiction to bring junkyard company's owner into action, when he was not named as employer by claimant.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: DeJesus v. R.P.M. Enterprises, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: The improper use of the corporate form is the key to the inquiry of whether the corporate veil should be pierced or not, as it is true that courts will disregard legal fictions, including that of a separate corporate entity, when they are used for fraudulent or illegal purposes; unless something of the kind is proven, however, to do so is to act in opposition to the public policy of the state as expressed in legislation concerning the formation and regulation of corporations.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Workers' Compensation. Workers' compensation commissioner lacked jurisdiction to bring junkyard company's owner into action, when he was not named as employer by claimant.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: DeJesus v. R.P.M. Enterprises, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Under the instrumentality rule for piercing the corporate veil, proof of three elements is required: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) that such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetuate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of the plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) that the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Workers' Compensation. Workers' compensation commissioner lacked jurisdiction to bring junkyard company's owner into action, when he was not named as employer by claimant.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Pado, Inc. v. SG Trademark Holding Co. LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, a party seeking to pierce a corporate veil must allege: (1) that the owner exercised complete domination over the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce the veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Patent owner failed to adequately plead facts justifying piercing corporate veil under New York law to hold competitor's owner directly liable for patent infringement.

Title: Alvarez Galvez v. Fanjul Corporation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: To establish a claim for piercing the corporate veil under Florida law, a plaintiff must allege that (1) the shareholder dominated and controlled the corporation to such an extent that the corporation's independent existence, was in fact non-existent and the shareholders were in fact alter egos of the corporation; (2) the corporate form was used fraudulently or for an improper purpose; and (3) the fraudulent or improper use of the corporate form caused injury to the claimant.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Jurisdiction. District Court lacked alienage jurisdiction over claims that sugar company forcibly evicted homeowners because both parties were foreign citizens.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Alvarez Galvez v. Fanjul Corporation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: The federal common law alter ego rule requires that three elements be proved in order to pierce the corporate veil: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practices in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; and (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Jurisdiction. District Court lacked alienage jurisdiction over claims that sugar company forcibly evicted homeowners because both parties were foreign citizens.

Title: Lyngaas v. Curaden Ag
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, whether corporate entity is mere instrumentality of another, thus warranting piercing corporate veil, is determined by analyzing (1) whether corporation is undercapitalized, (2) whether separate books are kept, (3) whether there are separate finances for corporation, (4) whether corporation is used for fraud or illegality, (5) whether corporate formalities have been followed, and (6) whether corporation is sham.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Consumer Protection. Swiss toothbrush manufacturer was not liable for its distributor's Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA) violations.

Title: EST Inc. v. Royal-Grow Prods., LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Under Kansas law, effect of alter ego doctrine is not to expand individual liability for individual actions; it is to bypass corporate form in only rarest of circumstances, such as, for example, fraud, such that individual becomes responsible for corporate liabilities when corporation cannot or will not meet its financial obligations. Kan. Stat. Ann. § 17-7101(b).
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS  Registration. Use of trademark on product shipment and sale documents did not constitute use in commerce, as prerequisite for registration of mark.

Title: Gold Crest, LLC v. Project Light, LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.

Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Design patent owner's allegations supported piercing corporate veil under Ohio law as to direct infringement claim against member of LLCs.

Title: In re Paul C. Larsen, P.A.

Title: Belliveau v. Barco, Incorporated
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, "piercing the corporate veil" is a remedy to be used when the actions of the entity's owner amounting to actual fraud have rendered the entity unable to pay its debts. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(b).

Title: Flores v. Westmont Engineering Company
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Fourth Division.
Headnote: Generally, before the separate corporate identity of one corporation will be disregarded and treated as the alter ego of another, it must be shown that it is so controlled and its affairs so conducted that it is a mere instrumentality of another, and it must further appear that observance of the fiction of separate existence would, under the circumstances, sanction a fraud or promote injustice.

Title: Steadfast Insurance Company v. T.F. Nugent Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, for purposes of piercing the corporate veil under an alter ego theory, the prong requiring that corporate domination was used to commit fraud can be satisfied either upon a showing of fraud or upon complete control that leads to a wrong against third parties.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Successor Liability. Insurer plausibly alleged painting company's successor was incorporated and created solely to hide business assets of company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Udelhoven
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, in order for liability to be fixed on shareholder on a veil-piercing theory, the liability must arise from a fraud or injustice perpetrated, not on the corporation, but on third persons dealing with the corporation.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debt arising out of unperformed contract to construct home could not be excepted from discharge on fraud theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Udelhoven
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, once it is shown that a sufficient unity of interest and ownership exists, corporate veil may be pierced upon a showing that maintaining the corporation's separate existence would either: (1) sanction a fraud, or (2) promote injustice; either showing will satisfy the second prong of veil-piercing test.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debt arising out of unperformed contract to construct home could not be excepted from discharge on fraud theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Sutton 58 Assocs. LLC v. Pilevsky
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Generally, a plaintiff seeking to pierce the corporate veil must show that (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil could not be pierced so as to hold individual borrowers personally liable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Prince v. Appleton Auto, LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Wisconsin law, piercing the corporate veil is appropriate only when applying the corporate fiction would accomplish some fraudulent purpose, operate as a constructive fraud, or defeat some strong equitable claim.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Discrimination. Corporate veil of affiliated network of corporations that were separate car dealerships would not be pierced to meet employee threshold for coverage under Title VII.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Cruz v. Fusion Buffet, Inc
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: The alter ego doctrine is applied, and a party other than the corporation is liable for the corporation's acts, when recognition of the corporate structure would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Attorney Fees. Evidence supported finding that employee did not bring claim under alter ego theory in bad faith, precluding attorney fee award in favor of officers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Hanamura-Valashinas v. Transitions by Firenza, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eleventh District, Lake County.
Headnote: The corporate form may be disregarded and individual shareholders held liable for wrongs committed by the corporation when (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong. (Per Lynch, J., with two judges concurring in judgment only.)
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Allegation by homeowners that managing partner falsified invoices before presenting them violated duty independent of construction agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Hanamura-Valashinas v. Transitions by Firenza, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eleventh District, Lake County.
Headnote: To fulfill the second prong of the Belvedere Condominium Unit Owners' Assn. v. R.E. Roark Cos., Inc., 67 Ohio St.3d 274, 617 N.E.2d 1075, test for piercing the corporate veil, the plaintiff must demonstrate that the defendant shareholder exercised control over the corporation in such a manner as to commit fraud, an illegal act, or a similarly unlawful act. (Per Lynch, J., with two judges concurring in judgment only.)
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Allegation by homeowners that managing partner falsified invoices before presenting them violated duty independent of construction agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Energy Conversion Devices, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Michigan law will disregard a corporation's separate existence and hold individual shareholders/owners personally liable when corporate form is used to commit a fraud or a wrong.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Energy Conversion Devices, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, there is a presumption that the corporate form will be respected, and corporate veil may be pierced only where an otherwise separate corporate existence has been used to subvert justice or cause a result that is contrary to some overriding public policy.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Trust established under confirmed plan stated actual fraudulent transfer claim based on confluence of fraud badges.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Energy Conversion Devices, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: In deciding whether to pierce corporate veil, Michigan courts, after determining that corporate entity was operated as mere instrumentality of its owner, must then determine whether this manner of use effected a fraud or wrong on the complainant; in this regard, it is not necessary to prove that the owner caused the corporate entity to directly harm complainant, as long as the owner exercised his or her control over the entity in such a manner as to wrong the complainant.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Trust established under confirmed plan stated actual fraudulent transfer claim based on confluence of fraud badges.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: City and County of San Francisco v. Purdue Pharma L.P.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: The alter-ego doctrine is not limited to intentional fraud, nor does it require bad faith; so long as there is a unity of interest and ownership, courts will ignore the corporate form and attribute wrongful or inequitable conduct to the organization controlling the corporation.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Advertising. City established standing to assert claim under California's False Advertising Law (FAL) against pharmaceutical companies that manufactured opioids.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Qun Lin v. Cruz
Court: Court of Special Appeals of Maryland.
Headnote: In Maryland, courts will allow a plaintiff to pierce the corporate veil and disregard the corporate fiction only in instances of fraud or when necessary to enforce a paramount equity.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Hours and Wages. Remand was warranted for court to determine whether purported owner was owner of restaurant either by piercing corporate veil or economic reality test under FLSA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Butler America, LLC v. Aviation Assurance Company, LLC
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 6, California.
Headnote: Ordinarily a corporation, or in this case a limited liability entity, is regarded as a separate legal entity, but where such an entity is used to perpetrate fraud or to accomplish some other wrongful or inequitable purpose, a court may disregard the entity and treat its acts as if done by the persons actually controlling it.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Judgment. Substantial evidence established that debtor's owner and related entities were its alter egos, warranting amendment of judgment to add them as debtors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Royal Alice Properties, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, traditional veil-piercing doctrines are generally limited to cases in which the separate existence of corporation has been abused, and in which court finds that piercing the corporate veil is necessary to remedy fraud, illegality, or other inequitable conduct by corporation's shareholders.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Common ownership and commingling of funds supported single business enterprise claim against debtor.

Title: Moss v. Associated Underwriters, Inc.

Headnote: A court will disregard a corporation's identity only where the corporation has been used to commit fraud, violate a legal duty, or perpetrate a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of the rights of another.

Title: Moss v. Associated Underwriters, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Nebraska.
Headnote: A plaintiff seeking to pierce the corporate veil must allege and prove that the corporation was under the actual control of the shareholder and that the shareholder exercised such control to commit a fraud or other wrong in contravention of the plaintiff's rights.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence warranted piercing corporate veil of insurance corporation to hold corporation's sole shareholder liable for unpaid judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Moss v. Associated Underwriters, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Nebraska.
Headnote: The separate entity concept of the corporation may be disregarded, and corporate veil pierced to impose liability on the shareholder, where the corporation is a mere shell, serving no legitimate business purpose, and is used as an intermediary to perpetuate fraud on the creditors.

Title: Edmonson v. State
Court: Court of Appeals of Mississippi.
Headnote: Although a basic legal principle holds that a corporation possesses a legal existence separate and apart from that of its officers, piercing the corporate veil is appropriate where a corporation exists to perpetuate a fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Edmonson v. State
Court: Court of Appeals of Mississippi.
Headnote: The principle that a corporate entity is separate from that of its owners, but corporate veil is pierced if corporation exists to perpetuate a fraud, applies in the criminal context as well.
Document Preview: CRIMINAL JUSTICE  Indictment and Information. Indictment sufficiently charged defendant individually for check fraud despite inclusion of name of his company that had checking account in issue.
