Title: Hartshorne v. Roman Catholic Diocese of Albany
Court: Supreme Court, New York, Schenectady County.
Headnote: Generally, a plaintiff seeking to pierce the corporate veil must show that (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Benefit Plans. Pension plan participants adequately alleged facts that, if true, would permit diocese to be held liable as employer's alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Nobel v. Foxmoor Group, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: There are three elements of a successful "instrumentality rule" claim, such that the corporate form may be disregarded, and the corporation and shareholder treated as same entity: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to transaction attacked so that corporate entity as to this transaction had at time no separate mind, will or existence of its own, (2) such control must have been used by defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Unfair Practices. Chief executive officer's inducement of investment and non-repayment of promissory note was not subject to Unfair and Deceptive Trade Practices Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Cambridge Valley Machining, Inc. v. Hudson MFG LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Texas law permits piercing the corporate veil to prevent fraud or to achieve equity. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(b).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Sales. Manufacturer's purported repudiation of contract to provide firearm components did not excuse buyer's performance.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Ingham v. Johnson & Johnson
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, DIVISION TWO.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, a plaintiff must prove three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: TORTS  Negligence. Specific personal jurisdiction existed over manufacturer of cosmetic products as to 15 non-resident consumers' complaints regarding shower product.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Matter of Avery Health Care Center
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth District, Franklin County.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil is a rare exception and only used in the case of fraud and certain other exceptional circumstances.
Document Preview: HEALTH  Residential Facilities. Owner of nursing home was not a principal participant in long-term care facility which had been issued a license revocation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: City of Long Beach v. Total Gas & Power North America, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: For an alter ego relationship to exist under federal common law, the controlling corporation must have used the corporate entity to perpetrate a fraud or have so dominated and disregarded the corporate entity's form that the entity primarily transacted the subservient entity's personal business rather than its own corporate business.
Document Preview: ANTITRUST  Monopolies. City that traded natural gas derivatives lacked antitrust standing to pursue Sherman Act claims against traders based on manipulation of monthly index prices.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: City of Long Beach v. Total Gas & Power North America, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, for alter ego relationship to exist, a showing of fraud or complete control by the dominating corporation that leads to a wrong against third parties is required.
Document Preview: ANTITRUST  Monopolies. City that traded natural gas derivatives lacked antitrust standing to pursue Sherman Act claims against traders based on manipulation of monthly index prices.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >

Title: International Union, United Mine Workers of America v. CONSOL Energy, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. West Virginia, at Bluefield.
Headnote: Factors for fully piercing the corporate veil include alleged fraud as well as lack of corporate formalities or abandonment of the corporate structure, among others.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Benefit Plans. As a matter of first impression, unions do not have associational standing to bring claims under a certain ERISA clause providing for a civil action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Areno
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Louisiana, Lafayette Division.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, one of the primary policies underlying the alter ego/veil piercing theories is to prevent an owner of an entity from using the business form to defraud creditors. La. Rev. Stat. Ann. § 12:95.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Under Louisiana law, as predicted by Bankruptcy Court, veil piercing doctrines under corporation law also applied to LLCs and their members.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Munsell v. Colgate-Palmolive Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, courts employ twelve factors to guide their veil-piercing analysis, including: (1) common ownership, (2) pervasive control, (3) confused intermingling of business assets, (4) thin capitalization, (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities, (6) absence of corporate records, (7) no payment of dividends, (8) insolvency at the time of the litigated transaction, (9) siphoning away of corporation's funds by dominant shareholder, (10) nonfunctioning of officers and directors, (11) use of the corporation for transactions of the dominant shareholders, and (12) use of the corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY  Industry Regulation. Buyer of personal care products plausibly alleged product labels had capacity to mislead.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Meadowfresh Solutions USA, LLC v. Maple Grove Farms, LLC
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Southern District, Division One.
Headnote: The requisite proof for establishing a claim for piercing the corporate veil requires: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) that such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) that the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Issue of whether company was alter ego was actually litigated and decided in prior jury trial, as necessary for estoppel to preclude relitigation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Arkansas Nursing Home Acquisition, LLC v. CFG Community Bank
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: In general, Maryland courts consider five factors when assessing an attempt to pierce the corporate veil of a corporation: (1) complete domination, not only of the finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) that such control was used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of the statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of the plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) that such control and breach of duty proximately caused the injury or unjust loss.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. Nursing home company failed to properly allege assets were transferred resulting in formation of retirement community LLC, as would support fraudulent conveyance.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Grayiel v. AIO Holdings, LLC
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Kentucky, Louisville Division.
Headnote: Under Kentucky law, to pierce a corporate veil, a court must find: (1) domination of the corporation resulting in a loss of corporate separateness, and (2) circumstances under which continued recognition of the corporation would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Fraudulent Transfers. Summary judgment was precluded on investor's actual fraudulent conveyance claim against entity allegedly involved in natural gas drilling scheme.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Gral
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Wisconsin.
Headnote: Under Wisconsin law, veil-piercing doctrine applies to overcome strong presumption that corporations and like entities are legally distinct from their owners when: (1) an individual owner uses his complete domination of an entity to commit a fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or to commit a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of another's legal rights, and (2) that misconduct proximately causes injury or loss.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Trustee's threadbare allegations did not state plausible fraudulent transfer avoidance claim.

Title: Doe v. Bausch & Lomb, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, a court will disregard the corporate structure and pierce the corporate veil only under exceptional circumstances, for example, where the corporation is a mere shell, serving no legitimate purpose, and used primarily as an intermediary to perpetuate fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: HEALTH  Medical Devices. Patient's failure-to-warn claim was preempted by Medical Device Amendments (MDA) to the Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (FDCA).

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Best Choice Roofing & Home Improvement, Inc. v. Best Choice Roofing Savannah, LLC
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Tennessee, Nashville Division.
Headnote: Under Tennessee law, factors to be considered in determining whether to disregard the corporate veil include not only whether the entity has been used to work a fraud or injustice in contravention of public policy, but also: (1) whether there was a failure to collect paid in capital; (2) whether the corporation was grossly undercapitalized; (3) the nonissuance of stock certificates; (4) the sole ownership of stock by one individual; (5) the use of the same office or business location; (6) the employment of the same employees or attorneys; (7) the use of the corporation as an instrumentality or business conduit for an individual or another corporation; (8) the diversion of corporate assets by or to a stockholder or other entity to the detriment of creditors, or the manipulation of assets and liabilities in another; (9) the use of the corporation as a subterfuge in illegal transactions; (10) the formation and use of the corporation to transfer to it the existing liability of another person or entity; and (11) the failure to maintain arms-length relationships among related entities.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Fact issue existed whether licensees suffered damages from licensor's alleged breach of contract for failure to provide notice and cure period, precluding summary judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Best Choice Roofing & Home Improvement, Inc. v. Best Choice Roofing Savannah, LLC
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Tennessee, Nashville Division.
Headnote: Party seeking to pierce the corporate veil under Tennessee law must show that complete dominion and control over a corporation was used to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetuate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of third parties' rights.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Fact issue existed whether licensees suffered damages from licensor's alleged breach of contract for failure to provide notice and cure period, precluding summary judgment.

Title: In re Thornton
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, C.D. Illinois.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, the type of fraud that cannot be sanctioned and compels veil-piercing arises when a corporation or limited liability company (LLC) is used as the alter ego for an individual and such a unity of interest exists so that the separateness of the individual and the entity should be disregarded.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Creditor failed to establish a unity of interest or alter ego as required to support veil-piercing of limited liability company owned by debtor.

Title: In re Thornton
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, C.D. Illinois.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, the type of fraud that supports veil-piercing exists when an entity such as a corporation or limited liability company (LLC) is used as a sham.

Title: Johnson Trustee of Operating Engineers Local #49 Health and Welfare Fund v. Charps Welding & Fabricating, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: A corporation acts as another's alter ego if the corporation is (1) controlled by another to the extent it has independent existence in form only and (2) used as a subterfuge to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, or perpetuate a fraud.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Attorney Fees. District court did not abuse its discretion by awarding attorney fees for time that employer spent opposing audit.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Clark Rigging & Rental Corp. v. Liberty Mutual Insurance Company
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: A party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must establish that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in the plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Plaintiff sufficiently alleged that limited liability company's alleged alter ego was in fact its alter ego.

Title: Clark Rigging & Rental Corp. v. Liberty Mutual Insurance Company
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: Wrongdoing necessary to pierce the corporate veil on an alter-ego theory does not necessarily require allegations of actual fraud; while fraud certainly satisfies the wrongdoing requirement, other claims of inequity or malfeasance will also suffice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Plaintiff sufficiently alleged that limited liability company's alleged alter ego was in fact its alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Ferrante v. Westin St. John Hotel Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. North Carolina, Eastern Division.
Headnote: When deciding to pierce the corporate veil, North Carolina courts consider (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only in finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own, (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Condominiums. Condominium developer's refusal to allow time share owners to use time share was not a breach of contract under the law of the U.S. Virgin Islands.

Title: Missouri Ozarks Radio, Network, Inc. v. Baugh
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Southern District, Division Two.
Headnote: For a court to disregard the business entity or pierce the corporate veil, a plaintiff must demonstrate that the entity had: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own, (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: E-COMMERCE  Internet. Internet domain name administrator's selling of domain name after unauthorized transfer of ownership gave rise to independent tort of conversion.

Title: In re Bullitt Utilities, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Kentucky.
Headnote: Under Kentucky law, corporate veil could not be pierced to hold corporation's sole shareholder liable for its debts, where corporation was not undercapitalized, and there was no evidence that corporate form was disregarded by its sole shareholder or by any of its officers or directors in an effort to defraud anyone.

Title: In re Bullitt Utilities, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Kentucky.
Headnote: Under Kentucky law, decision to pierce corporate veil depends on two dispositive elements: (1) domination of corporation resulting in a loss of corporate separateness, and (2) circumstances under which continued recognition of the corporation would sanction fraud or promote injustice.

Title: General Fidelity Insurance Company v. WFT, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: While a corporation's separate and independent existence from its shareholders is not to be disregarded lightly, courts should disregard the corporate form when it would accomplish some fraudulent purpose, operate as a constructive fraud, or defeat some strong equitable claim.

Title: Mou v. SSC San Jose Operating Company LP
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California, San Jose Division.
Headnote: Under the California "alter ego doctrine," when the corporate form is used to perpetrate a fraud, circumvent a statute, or accomplish some other wrongful or inequitable purpose, the courts will ignore the corporate entity and deem the corporation's acts to be those of the persons or organizations actually controlling the corporation, in most instances the equitable owners.

Title: TrueNorth Companies, L.C. v. TruNorth Warranty Plans of North America, LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Iowa, Cedar Rapids Division.
Headnote: In determining whether the corporate veil should be pierced under Iowa law, the court should consider whether: (1) the corporation is undercapitalized, (2) without separate books, (3) its finances are not kept separate from individual finances, individual obligations are paid by the corporation, (4) the corporation is used to promote fraud or illegality, (5) corporate formalities are not followed or (6) the corporation is merely a sham.

Title: Binsara, LLC v. Bolog
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Fifth District, Stark County.
Headnote: The focus of the test to decide whether to pierce the corporate veil is the extent to which the shareholder controlled the corporation and whether the shareholder misused his or her control to commit specific egregious acts that injured the plaintiff: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud, an illegal act, or a similarly unlawful act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate officers engaged in fraud by entering into contract when corporation was not legal entity, and thus corporate veil could be pierced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Cerner Middle East Limited v. iCapital, LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Missouri law, the corporate veil may be pierced and a court may conclude that an individual shareholder is the corporation's alter ego if (1) the shareholder exerted control over the corporation, which had "no separate mind, will or existence of its own," (2) that control was used by the corporation to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of the plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) the control and breach of duty proximately caused the injury complained of.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Arbitration. Decision by Court of Appeals of Paris deserved recognition under principles of international comity.

Title: Crosskey Architects, LLC v. Poko Partners, LLC
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: The instrumentality rule, as used to determine whether piercing the corporate veil is proper, has three prongs, the first of which requires control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own, second, that such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of the plaintiff's legal rights, and third, that the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.

Title: North American Bullion Exchange, LLC v. CC Trading, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. North Dakota, EASTERN DIVISION.
Headnote: The corporate veil may be pierced under North Dakota law when the legal entity is used to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, protect fraud, or defend crime.
Document Preview: TORTS  Conversion. Fact issue as to whether a contract existed between buyer and seller precluded summary judgment on unjust enrichment and conversion claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Russell Barnett Ford of Tullahoma, Inc. v. H & S Bakery, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Tennessee, Winchester Division.
Headnote: Under Tennessee law, when considering whether to pierce the corporate veil, courts will consider whether the corporation was used to commit fraud or wrongdoing, but must also consider the following factors: (1) whether there was a failure to collect paid in capital, (2) whether the corporation was grossly undercapitalized, (3) the non-issuance of stock certificates, (4) the sole ownership of stock by one individual, (5) the use of the same office or business location, (6) the employment of the same employees or attorneys, (7) the use of the corporation as an instrumentality or business conduit for an individual or another corporation, (8) the diversion of corporate assets by or to a stockholder or other entity to the detriment of creditors, or the manipulation of assets and liabilities in another, (9) the use of the corporation as a subterfuge in illegal transactions, (10) the formation and use of the corporation to transfer to it the existing liability of another person or entity, and (11) the failure to maintain arms length relationships among related entities; not every factor needs to be met, nor will any single factor be dispositive in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Bakery business was not a party to contract for sale of commercial vehicles, and thus, could not be held liable for breach of that contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Watamar Holding S.A. v. SFM Holdings, S.A.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: While fraud may be relevant to piercing corporate veil for liability purposes, it has no place in assessing contact to determine jurisdiction.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Jurisdiction. Trial court lacked personal jurisdiction over nonresident defendants and Swiss holding corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: McKay v. Longman
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: The corporate veil is pierced only under exceptional circumstances, for example, where the corporation is a mere shell, serving no legitimate purpose, and is used primarily as an intermediary to perpetuate fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Outsider reverse veil piercing is recognized despite prospective legislative prohibition.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Trujillo
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: Under Florida law, a general principle of corporate law is that shareholders of a corporation are protected against personal liability unless it be shown that the corporation is formed or used for some illegal, fraudulent or other unjust purpose which justifies piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Debtor was equitable owner of Panamanian foundation, such that assets of foundation were property of the bankruptcy estate subject to turnover.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Kahan Jewelry Corp. v. Coin Dealer of 47th St. Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil and hold individual defendants liable for a corporation's actions, plaintiffs are required to show that (1) the individual owners exercised complete domination over the corporation with respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff, resulting in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. In breach of contract claim, plaintiffs failed to show that individual owners of corporate defendants could be held liable for corporation's actions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Draw Another Circle.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, to state a claim for veil piercing, the plaintiff must plead facts supporting an inference that the corporation, through an alter ego, created an entity designed to defraud its investors and creditors.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Liquidating trustee stated claim against debtor's board chair for breach of fiduciary duty.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: R&M Mixed Beverage Consultants, Inc. v. Safe Harbor Benefits, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, El Paso.
Headnote: In determination of whether there is evidence of abuse, as required to pierce the corporate veil, the kinds of abuse that the corporate structure should not shield are fraud, evasion of existing obligations, circumvention of statutes, monopolization, criminal conduct, and the like; abuse does not mean a subjective perception of unfairness by an individual judge or juror.
Document Preview: INSURANCE  Liability. Insurance entities that helped procure liquor liability insurance were not liable for damages resulting from the insurer's subsequent insolvency.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: R&M Mixed Beverage Consultants, Inc. v. Safe Harbor Benefits, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, El Paso.
Headnote: Although "actual fraud" is not statutorily defined, the term is construed for purposes of piercing the corporate veil, as involving dishonesty of purpose or intent to deceive. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(b).
Document Preview: INSURANCE  Liability. Insurance entities that helped procure liquor liability insurance were not liable for damages resulting from the insurer's subsequent insolvency.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Piller v. Princeton Realty Associates LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: An alter ego will be established when either (1) there is complete domination of a corporation by an individual with respect to the transaction being attacked that resulted in a fraud or wrong against the complaining party, or (2) when a corporation has been so dominated by an individual that it primarily transacts the dominator's business instead of its own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Judgment. Arbitration award barred, under res judicata doctrine, LLC member's allegations that other member breached certain pre-arbitration promises.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Denny v. Breawick, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Third District, Hancock County.
Headnote: To satisfy second prong of test for piercing the corporate veil, a plaintiff must demonstrate that a defendant shareholder exercised control over the corporation in such a manner as to commit fraud, an illegal act, or a similarly unlawful act; unjust or inequitable conduct in the absence of fraud, an illegal act, or an unlawful act is not sufficient.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Contractor had such complete control over his companies that they had no separate mind of their own, as necessary to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Blast Fitness Group, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In deciding whether to apply doctrine of corporate disregard in order to treat corporation as alter ego of its dominant shareholder or shareholders, Massachusetts courts consider the following relevant factors: (1) common ownership; (2) pervasive control; (3) confused intermingling of business assets; (4) thin capitalization; (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) no payment of dividends; (8) insolvency at time of the litigated transaction; (9) siphoning away of corporation's funds by dominant shareholder; (10) nonfunctioning of officers and directors; (11) use of the corporation for transactions of the dominant shareholders; and (12) use of corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Chapter 7 trustee stated plausible claim for veil piercing and/or alter ego determination against affiliated entities under Massachusetts law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Martin Hilti Family Trust v. Knoedler Gallery, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: When determining whether a corporation and its dominant shareholder operate as a single economic entity, such that it may pierce corporate veil and impose liability on shareholder, a plaintiff need not prove the corporation was created with fraud or unfairness in mind; it is sufficient to prove that it was so used.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Fraudulent Transfers. Art gallery's owner was not liable to foreign trust for Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Blast Fitness Group, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, while corporations and their shareholders are generally deemed to be distinct legal entities, a court may, under unusual circumstances, disregard the separateness of entities, particularly to defeat fraud or to remedy an injury.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Trustee stated plausible strong-arm claim to avoid transfer of right to acquire real estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Blast Fitness Group, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, while corporations and their shareholders are generally deemed to be distinct legal entities, a court may, under unusual circumstances, disregard the separateness of entities, particularly to defeat fraud or to remedy an injury.

Title: Singh v. Nadlan, LLC

Headnote: Generally, piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Linus Holding Corp. v. Mark Line Industries, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: In the absence of extraordinary circumstances, such as fraud or injustice, a court will generally decline to pierce the corporate veil under New Jersey law.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Real estate developer's contentions did not demonstrate that limited liability company functioned as a dummy or shell corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Linus Holding Corp. v. Mark Line Industries, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Even in instances where one individual shareholder or director dominates the corporate entity, liability generally is imposed by piercing the corporate veil, under New Jersey law, only where the dominant party has abused the privilege of incorporation by using the corporate form to perpetrate a fraud or injustice, or otherwise to circumvent the law.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Real estate developer's contentions did not demonstrate that limited liability company functioned as a dummy or shell corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Linus Holding Corp. v. Mark Line Industries, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: In determining whether circumstances indicate that adherence to the fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice, for purposes of piercing the corporate veil under New Jersey law, a plaintiff need not prove common law fraud but instead demonstrate that the defendants, via the corporate form, perpetrated a fraud, injustice, or the like, a less exacting standard.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Real estate developer's contentions did not demonstrate that limited liability company functioned as a dummy or shell corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Cestaro
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut, New Haven Division.
Headnote: Connecticut courts are reluctant to pierce corporate veil and will apply that remedy only in exceptional circumstances, as, for example, when corporation is mere shell, serving no legitimate purpose, and used primarily as an intermediary to perpetuate fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Plaintiff failed to demonstrate requisite deficiency in debtor's financial records based on unpreserved records of defunct business.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Cestaro
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut, New Haven Division.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, courts will disregard legal fictions, including that of a separate corporate entity, when such fictions are used for fraudulent or illegal purposes; however, unless something of the kind is proven, veil-piercing is in opposition to public policy of the State as expressed in legislation concerning the formation and regulation of corporations.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Plaintiff failed to demonstrate requisite deficiency in debtor's financial records based on unpreserved records of defunct business.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Bennett v. Garner
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: When an individual uses a corporate form to disguise wrongs, obscure fraud, or conceal crime, Virginia law permits a plaintiff to pierce the corporate veil and to impose liability directly on the individual as the alter ego of the corporation.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Judgment. State court judgment confirming arbitration award did not preclude employee's fraudulent transfer claims under doctrine of res judicata.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Bates Energy Oil & Gas v. Complete Oilfield Services
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Texas, San Antonio Division.
Headnote: A plaintiff, under Texas law, may impose individual liability against corporate agents by imposing vicarious liability on the individual for the corporation's liability through one of the various veil piercing theories for disregarding the corporate form, including sham to perpetrate a fraud or alter ego.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Jurisdiction. Purchaser adequately alleged that defendant had sufficient purposeful contacts with Texas, and thus district court had specific personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Rilley v. MoneyMutual, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, court may pierce corporate veil to hold party liable for corporate entity's acts if entity is used for fraudulent purpose or party is entity's alter ego.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Class Actions. Consumers satisfied requirements for class certification in action against companies that operated lead-generating business for payday lenders.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Skat Tax Refund Scheme Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To plead alter ego liability under New York law, the plaintiff must allege that: (1) the person exercised dominion and control with respect to the transaction attacked such that the corporation had no separate will of its own; and (2) the domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff, which proximately caused the plaintiff's injuries.
Document Preview: TORTS  Jurisdiction. Customs and Tax Administration did not seek direct enforcement of Danish tax law, and therefore revenue rule did not apply.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Trujillo
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: The test under Florida law to establish a claim for alter ego/piercing the corporate veil has three parts: (1) the shareholder dominated and controlled the corporation to such an extent that the corporation's independent existence, was in fact non-existent and the shareholders were in fact alter egos of the corporation; (2) the corporate form must have been used fraudulently or for an improper purpose; and (3) the fraudulent or improper use of the corporate form caused injury to the claimant.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Trustee was not barred from asserting alter ego claim under Florida law, even though debtor was not a shareholder of any of the corporate defendants.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: D'Amico Dry D.A.C. v. Primera Maritime (Hellas) Limited
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil under federal maritime law, a plaintiff must show that an alter ego was used to perpetuate a fraud or was so dominated and its corporate form so disregarded that the alter ego primarily transacted another entity's business rather than its own corporate business.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Successor Liability. Ship management company was liable as a successor-in-interest for judgment incurred by predecessor in English court.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Howe v. Links Club Condominium Association, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Courts will disregard the corporate form, or pierce the corporate veil, and extend liability for corporate obligations beyond the confines of a corporation's separate entity, whenever necessary to prevent fraud or to achieve equity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Allegations by minority unit owners in condominium complex sufficiently stated claim for piercing condominium association's corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Howe v. Links Club Condominium Association, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: To succeed in inquiry of whether a noncorporate defendant may be held liable for her personal actions as an officer or director after fact finder determines corporate veil should be pierced, plaintiffs must present evidence of three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to transaction attacked so that corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; and (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of a plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Allegations by minority unit owners in condominium complex sufficiently stated claim for piercing condominium association's corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Tully v. Mirz
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division.
Headnote: In an action by a corporation's shareholders, only upon proof of fraud or injustice will the corporate veil be pierced to impose liability on the corporate principals.

Title: Minico Insurance Agency, LLC v. AJP Contracting Corp.

Title: In re Stage Presence, Inc.

Title: Mirage Entertainment, Inc. v. FEG Entretenimientos S.A.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: A court may pierce the corporate veil under New York law where (1) the owner exercised complete domination over the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue, and (2) such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce the veil.

Title: Belair Care Center, Inc. v. Cool Insuring Agency, Inc.

Title: WFG National Title Insurance Company v. Meehan
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth District, Cuyahoga County.
Headnote: The current test for piercing the corporate veil in Ohio provides that the corporate form may be disregarded and individual shareholders held liable for wrongs committed by the corporation when: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud, an illegal act, or a similarly unlawful conduct or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity; and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.

Title: Meinert Plumbing v. Warner Industries, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth District, Cuyahoga County.
Headnote: The current test for whether piercing the corporate veil can occur considers whether: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud, an illegal act, or a similarly unlawful conduct or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Dealers were not entitled to pierce corporate veil in suits against manufacturing corporation and its parent corporations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Stisser v. SP Bancorp, Inc.
Court: Court of Special Appeals of Maryland.
Headnote: Maryland is more restrictive than other jurisdictions in allowing a plaintiff to pierce a corporate veil; the corporate fiction will be disregarded only in instances of fraud or when necessary to enforce a paramount equity.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Jurisdiction. Texas-incorporated bank holding company whose Maryland subsidiary merged with Maryland-incorporated company was not subject to specific jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Turman v. Superior Court of Orange County
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: Under the "alter ego doctrine," when the corporate form is used to perpetrate a fraud, circumvent a statute, or accomplish some other wrongful or inequitable purpose, the courts will ignore the corporate entity and deem the corporation's acts to be those of the persons or organizations actually controlling the corporation, in most instances the equitable owners.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Hours and Wages. Trial court employed improper tests when determining alter ego and joint employer issues.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Gucciardo
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, the elements necessary to pierce the corporate veil are a showing that the individual defendant(s): (1) exercised complete dominion and control over the corporation, and (2) used such dominion and control to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in injury.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debtor, as borrower's principal, did not cause willful and malicious injury to judgment creditors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Stoner v. Montpelier Tavern Company
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Sixth District, Williams County.
Headnote: The corporate form may be disregarded and individual shareholders held liable for wrongs committed by the corporation when: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: TORTS  Negligence. Patron injured in bar fight failed to demonstrate foreseeability of violence required to established negligence claim against bar.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Thomas v. Khrawesh
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: When analyzing the three factors considered by Michigan courts in determining whether to hold corporate officers personally liable, courts also consider the undercapitalization of the corporation, the maintenance of separate books, the separation of corporate and individual finances, the use of the corporation to support fraud or illegality, the honoring of corporate formalities, and whether the corporation is merely a sham.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Former employee of dissolved corporation could pierce corporate veil to collect, from corporation's owner, default judgment previously awarded against corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Thomas v. Khrawesh
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Michigan law does not require a showing of fraud or illegality before the corporate form will be disregarded; instead, corporate officers may be liable for conduct short of the illegal that makes unjustified use of the corporate form.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Former employee of dissolved corporation could pierce corporate veil to collect, from corporation's owner, default judgment previously awarded against corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Chapco, Inc. v. Woodway USA, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, the instrumentality rule, as basis for piercing the corporate veil, requires, in any case but an express agency, proof of three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) that such control was used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty or a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of the plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) that the control and breach of duty proximately caused the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: PATENTS  Consumer Goods. Alleged infringer's treadmill products infringed on patentee's patent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Cedillo
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, piercing the corporate veil requires showing that: (1) corporation's owners exercised complete domination of corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff, which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Immigrant debtor's English-illiteracy bears on whether financial statement was submitted fraudulently.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Cedillo
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: While complete domination of corporation is key to piercing the corporate veil under New York law, some showing of fraud or of wrongful or unjust act toward plaintiff is required.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Immigrant debtor's English-illiteracy bears on whether financial statement was submitted fraudulently.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Highland CDO Opportunity Master Fund, L.P. v. Citibank, N.A.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil under Texas law, plaintiff must establish actual fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Investment fund's management company was not liable under veil piercing theory for fund's breach of agreements governing credit default swaps.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Highland CDO Opportunity Master Fund, L.P. v. Citibank, N.A.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil under New York law, plaintiff need only establish fraud or wrong.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Investment fund's management company was not liable under veil piercing theory for fund's breach of agreements governing credit default swaps.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Highland CDO Opportunity Master Fund, L.P. v. Citibank, N.A.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil under New York law, plaintiff must establish that: (1) owner exercised complete domination over corporation with respect to transaction at issue, and (2) such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong that injured party seeking to pierce veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Investment fund's management company was not liable under veil piercing theory for fund's breach of agreements governing credit default swaps.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Highland CDO Opportunity Master Fund, L.P. v. Citibank, N.A.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, ordinary breach of contract, without evidence of fraud or corporate misconduct, is not sufficient to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Investment fund's management company was not liable under veil piercing theory for fund's breach of agreements governing credit default swaps.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Highland CDO Opportunity Master Fund, L.P. v. Citibank, N.A.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, equitable ownership theory is not alternative to veil piercing, but rather recognition that veil piercing can apply to someone who is not corporation's legal owner if he exercises sufficient control and uses that control to commit fraud or wrong.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Investment fund's management company was not liable under veil piercing theory for fund's breach of agreements governing credit default swaps.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Spano v. V & J National Enterprises, LLC
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, evidence of domination alone does not suffice to pierce corporate veil without an additional showing that it led to inequity, fraud or malfeasance.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Arbitration. Non-signatory restaurant operators received direct benefit from arbitration agreement and, thus, were estopped from avoiding arbitration.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Kelleher v. Dream Catcher, L.L.C.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: In determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, courts generally inquire as to whether corporate formalities have been observed, whether there has been commingling of corporate and shareholder funds, staff and property, whether a single shareholder dominates the corporation, whether the corporation is adequately capitalized, and, especially, whether the corporate form has been used to effectuate a fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Homeowner plausibly alleged that owners of construction LLC were alter egos of LLC, and thus, could be held individually liable on homeowner's claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Cohen v. Meyers
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Ordinarily the corporate veil is pierced only under exceptional circumstances, for example, where the corporation is a mere shell, serving no legitimate purpose, and used primarily as an intermediary to perpetuate fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Homeowner failed to satisfy instrumentality test, as required to pierce construction company's corporate veil and hold president individually liable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Howard Town Center Developer, LLC v. Howard University
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: In the District of Columbia, a party seeking to disregard the corporate entity must prove by affirmative evidence that there is (1) unity of ownership and interest, and (2) use of the corporate form to perpetuate fraud or wrong.
Document Preview: EDUCATION  Property and Contracts. Under District of Columbia law, university landowner provided proper notice to developer prior to terminating ground lease and development agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Curci Investments, LLC v. Baldwin
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: Ordinarily a corporation is considered a separate legal entity, distinct from its stockholders, officers and directors, with separate and distinct liabilities and obligations, and the same is true of a limited liability company (LLC) and its members and managers; however, under the "alter ego doctrine," that legal separation may be disregarded when the corporation or LLC is used by one or more individuals to perpetrate a fraud, circumvent a statute, or accomplish some other wrongful or inequitable purpose. Cal. Corp. Code § 17703.04(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Judgment creditor was not per se precluded from reverse piercing corporate veil to add LLC, in which judgment debtor held interest, to judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: State ex rel. Family Support Division v. Steak'm Take'm LLC
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: Missouri law permits a court to "pierce the corporate veil" where the following factors are shown: (1) control, meaning complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own, (2) such control must have been used by the corporation to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) the control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Trial court could pierce corporate veil of restaurant organized as LLC to find operator personally liable for debt owed to state child support division.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: State ex rel. Family Support Division v. Steak'm Take'm LLC
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: In order to establish the second prong of the test for piercing the corporate veil, i.e., that the complete control was used to commit fraud or wrongdoing, the plaintiff need not show actual fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Trial court could pierce corporate veil of restaurant organized as LLC to find operator personally liable for debt owed to state child support division.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: LaMusga v. Summit Square Rehab, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Second District, Montgomery County.
Headnote: In order to reach the personal assets of a corporation's individual shareholders, a creditor must show that (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Employer's Liability. Security officer training company was not liable for death allegedly caused by actions of guards trained by company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: United States v. TDC Management Corp.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under District of Columbia law, plaintiff does not need to show actual fraud perpetrated through use of the corporate form in order to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Under alter ego theory, assets of corporation owned by judgment debtor were subject to garnishment by federal government as judgment creditor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Zak
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, there are certain circumstances in which court may disregard the corporate form, particularly where corporation is solely owned and controlled by one individual and used to perpetrate fraud.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debtor's breached duties as partner to account for profits were fiduciary defalcations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Sigma–Tech Sales, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida, Fort Lauderdale Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, the corporate veil will be pierced and the corporate entity disregarded if it is shown that the corporation is formed or used for some illegal, fraudulent or other unjust purpose which justifies piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Under Florida law, president was alter ego of Chapter 7 corporation, and thus was liable for its debts.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Sigma–Tech Sales, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida, Fort Lauderdale Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, improper conduct exists, justifying piercing the corporate veil, where a corporation is used as a subterfuge to mislead or defraud creditors, to hide assets, to evade the requirements of a statute or some analogous betrayal of trust.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Under Florida law, president was alter ego of Chapter 7 corporation, and thus was liable for its debts.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Louis Dreyfus Company Freight Asia Pte LTD v. Uttam Galva Metallics Limited
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under federal common law, veil-piercing is permissible where an entity uses its alter ego to perpetrate a fraud and where one entity so dominates and disregards its alter ego's corporate form that the controlling entity is primarily transacting its own business through its alter ego.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW  Attachment. Vacatur was appropriate of order of maritime attachment obtained by global merchant company against steel manufacturers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Glick
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: There are two requirements before piercing the corporate veil: first, the court must find that the shareholder dominated the corporation to the point that it had no separate existence and was effectively his alter ego, and second, the court must conclude that failing to set aside corporate identity and hold the shareholder liable would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Trustee failed to adequately plead fraudulent transfer claims with the necessary particularity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Glick
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Two requirements must be met before an Illinois court will pierce the corporate veil: the court must find that the shareholder dominated the corporation to the point that it had no separate existence and was effectively his alter ego, and second, the court must conclude that failing to ignore corporate identity and holding the shareholder liable would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Trustee failed to adequately plead fraudulent transfer claims with the necessary particularity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Cluck-U Chicken, Inc. v. Cluck-U Corp.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Tampa Division.
Headnote: Under Maryland law, although the courts will, in a proper case, disregard the corporate entity and deal with substance rather than form, as though a corporation did not exist, shareholders generally are not held individually liable for debts or obligations of a corporation except where it is necessary to prevent fraud or enforce a paramount equity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Franchises and Dealerships. Issues of fact as to misrepresentations and omissions in franchise disclosure document and investigation of franchise precluded summary judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: LiquidX Inc. v. Brooklawn Capital, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, court may pierce the corporate veil whenever necessary to prevent fraud or achieve equity.
