Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: LiquidX Inc. v. Brooklawn Capital, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Generally, under New York law, piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Successor was indistinguishable from predecessor company, as would support compelling it to participate in arbitration with predecessor's creditor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Ritz
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, to pierce the corporate veil and hold a shareholder personally liable requires a showing that the shareholder caused the corporation to be used for the purpose of perpetrating and did perpetrate an actual fraud on the plaintiff primarily for the direct personal benefit of the shareholder. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(b).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debtor's transfers out of company he financially controlled were made with actual intent to hinder, delay, or defraud creditor under TUFTA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Cohen v. Schroeder
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, a veil piercing party must show that defendant's abuse of the corporate form in and of itself operates to serve some fraud or injustice, distinct from the alleged wrongs of the underlying corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing the corporate veil to impose personal liability on majority owner in small, privately-held Delaware corporation was unwarranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Commonwealth v. Golden Gate National Senior Care LLC
Court: Commonwealth Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: The fraud or similar injustice that must be demonstrated to pierce a corporate veil under Delaware law must, in particular, be found in the defendants' use of the corporate form.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Unfair Practices. Marketing statements regarding services at nursing facilities were puffery not actionable as false advertising under unfair trade practices law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Commonwealth v. Golden Gate National Senior Care LLC
Court: Commonwealth Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil under Delaware law's alter-ego theory, requiring that the corporate structure cause fraud or similar injustice, the term "similar injustice" includes the contravention of law or contract.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Unfair Practices. Marketing statements regarding services at nursing facilities were puffery not actionable as false advertising under unfair trade practices law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Commonwealth v. Golden Gate National Senior Care LLC
Court: Commonwealth Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: While there is no bright-line test for when to pierce the corporate veil, courts consider the following factors: (1) undercapitalization, (2) failure to adhere to the corporate formalities, (3) substantial intermingling of corporate and personal affairs, and (4) use of the corporate form to perpetrate a fraud.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Unfair Practices. Marketing statements regarding services at nursing facilities were puffery not actionable as false advertising under unfair trade practices law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Enron Corporation Securities, Derivative & "ERISA" Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: As a tool of equity, under Delaware law, the corporate fiction may be disregarded to prevent fraud, and a wholly-owned subsidiary may sometimes be treated as an instrumentality of the parent.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION  Fraud. Alleged conduct in helping corporation create a false public image of its financial strength was not cognizable under § 10(b).

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Enron Corporation Securities, Derivative & "ERISA" Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: To show that an overall element of injustice or unfairness is present, as required to pierce the corporate veil under Delaware law, the plaintiff must show fraud or injustice inherent in the defendant's use of the corporate form; however the underlying cause of action, at least by itself, does not supply the necessary fraud or injustice, but is distinct from the tort alleged in the suit.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION  Fraud. Alleged conduct in helping corporation create a false public image of its financial strength was not cognizable under § 10(b).

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Enron Corporation Securities, Derivative & "ERISA" Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil under Delaware law, the corporate structure must cause the fraud, and the fraud or injustice must be found in the defendants' use of the corporate form; the corporation must be a fraud or a sham existing only for the purpose of serving as a vehicle for fraud.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION  Fraud. Alleged conduct in helping corporation create a false public image of its financial strength was not cognizable under § 10(b).

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Commonwealth v. Tradition (North America) Inc.
Court: Appeals Court of Massachusetts, Suffolk.
Headnote: The corporate veil may be pierced where the corporate principal exercises (1) some form of pervasive control over the activities of the corporation, and (2) there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence as a result.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Settlements. Contribution claims were barred due to Commonwealth and broker entering into settlement that did not discharge common liability of all joint tortfeasors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Fausse Riviere, L.L.C. v. Snyder
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Court may pierce the corporate veil under two exceptional circumstances: first, where the shareholders, acting through the corporation, commit fraud or deceit on a third party, the court will look to the shareholders for justice; secondly, the court may disregard the corporate identity where shareholders fail to conduct the business on a corporate footing, which failure can occur if the shareholder disregarded the corporate formalities to such an extent that the shareholder and the corporation became indistinguishable, or such unity existed that separate individualities ceased and the corporation was operated as the alter ego of the shareholder.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Landlord and Tenant. Land lessor was judicially estopped from asserting forfeiture and abandonment claim as to lessee's remaining property on the land.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Hintze
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Florida, GAINESVILLE DIVISION.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil under Florida law, it must be shown that the corporation was organized or employed to mislead creditors or to work a fraud upon them, and a showing of improper conduct is also required.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debtors, by causing wholly-owned entity to transfer its assets to friendly creditor, transferred their own property, for discharge-denial purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Hintze
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Florida, GAINESVILLE DIVISION.
Headnote: "Improper conduct," as required to pierce the corporate veil under Florida law, exists where a corporation is used as a mere subterfuge to mislead or defraud creditors, to hide assets, or to evade the requirements of a statute, or where there is some analogous betrayal of trust.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debtors, by causing wholly-owned entity to transfer its assets to friendly creditor, transferred their own property, for discharge-denial purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Hintze
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Florida, GAINESVILLE DIVISION.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil under Florida law, claimant has heavy burden to prove by a preponderance of the evidence that: (1) shareholder dominated and controlled corporation to such extent that corporation's independent existence was in fact non-existent and shareholder was in fact alter ego of corporation, (2) corporate form was used fraudulently or for improper purpose, and (3) fraudulent or improper use of corporate form caused injury to claimant.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debtors, by causing wholly-owned entity to transfer its assets to friendly creditor, transferred their own property, for discharge-denial purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Ryan Racing, LLC v. Gentilozzi
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, a veil-piercing remedy is available under the instrumentality rule when the owner's use of the corporate entity effected a fraud or wrong on the complainant.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment debtor was undercapitalized, weighing in favor of piercing corporate veil to permit judgment creditor to collect judgment from judgment debtor's owner.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Ryan Racing, LLC v. Gentilozzi
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, a showing of fraud is not necessary to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment debtor was undercapitalized, weighing in favor of piercing corporate veil to permit judgment creditor to collect judgment from judgment debtor's owner.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Rouette
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut, New Haven Division.
Headnote: Connecticut courts are reluctant to pierce corporate veil, and apply that remedy only in exceptional circumstances, such as when corporation is mere shell, that serves no legitimate purpose, and that is used primarily as intermediary to perpetuate fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Corporate creditor had no claim against individual debtor-shareholders' Chapter 7 estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Rouette
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut, New Haven Division.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, whether there has been improper use of corporate form is key inquiry for court when deciding whether to veil-pierce; while it is true that courts will disregard legal fictions, including that of a separate corporate entity, when they are used for fraudulent or illegal purposes, unless something of that kind is proven, veil-piercing is contrary to Connecticut public policy as expressed in legislation concerning the formation and regulation of corporations.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Corporate creditor had no claim against individual debtor-shareholders' Chapter 7 estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Rouette
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut, New Haven Division.
Headnote: Connecticut courts decline to pierce the veil of even the closest corporations in the absence of proof that failure to do so will perpetrate a fraud or other injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Corporate creditor had no claim against individual debtor-shareholders' Chapter 7 estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Rouette
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut, New Haven Division.
Headnote: In order to pierce corporate veil under Connecticut's instrumentality rule, plaintiff must establish three elements by a preponderance of the evidence: (1) that shareholders so controlled corporation with respect to the transaction attacked that corporation had no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) that shareholders used this control to commit a fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) that control and wrong-doing of shareholders proximately caused plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Corporate creditor had no claim against individual debtor-shareholders' Chapter 7 estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Southern Shores Realty Services, Inc. v. Miller
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: General rule is that in the ordinary course of business, a corporation is treated as distinct from its shareholders; however, exceptions to the general rule of corporate insularity may be made when applying the corporate fiction would accomplish some fraudulent purpose, operate as a constructive fraud, or defeat some strong equitable claim, and those who are responsible for the existence of the corporation are, in those situations, prevented from using its separate existence to accomplish an unconscionable result.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Owners of vacation rentals breached contracts requiring notification to management company and return of deposits for properties in foreclosure.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Southern Shores Realty Services, Inc. v. Miller
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Courts will disregard the corporate form or pierce the corporate veil, and extend liability for corporate obligations beyond the confines of a corporation's separate entity, whenever necessary to prevent fraud or to achieve equity.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Owners of vacation rentals breached contracts requiring notification to management company and return of deposits for properties in foreclosure.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: FDASmart, Inc. v. Dishman Pharmaceuticals and Chemicals Limited
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division.
Headnote: Where individuals set up legitimate business structures to further their personal and business plans and do not use their partnerships to commit fraud or defeat the ends of justice, the veil-piercing doctrine will not apply.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporation's wholly owned subsidiary was not dominated by its parent corporation, and thus, corporation's corporate veil could not be pierced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Viajes Gerpa, S.A. v. Fazeli
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Alter ego or other similar theories may be used to pierce the corporate veil only if: (1) actual fraud is shown and (2) it was perpetrated primarily for the direct personal benefit of the corporation's shareholder, beneficial owner, subscriber, or affiliate. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Debt Collection. Owner was not individually liable for debt incurred before corporation forfeited its charter for failure to pay franchise taxes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Petters Company, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, disregard of corporate entity is an equitable remedy, that is generally not available absent fraud.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Trustee could bring preference claims, though debtors lacked creditors other than recipients of alleged preferential transfers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Petters Company, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: For the corporate veil to be pierced under Delaware law, corporate structure must cause fraud or similar injustice; effectively, corporation must be a sham and exist for no other purpose than as vehicle for fraud.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Trustee could bring preference claims, though debtors lacked creditors other than recipients of alleged preferential transfers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Petters Company, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: In order to state veil-piercing claim under Delaware law, plaintiff must plead facts supporting an inference that corporation, through its alter ego, has created a sham entity designed to defraud investors and creditors.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Trustee could bring preference claims, though debtors lacked creditors other than recipients of alleged preferential transfers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Supreme Energy, LLC v. Martens
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Generally piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in the plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - Oil and Gas. Monetary fine of $1,269,517 against operator of onshore major petroleum storage facility was not abuse of discretion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Mason Tenders District Council of Greater New York v. Phase Construction Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, to pierce the corporate veil, plaintiff must establish (1) that owner exercised complete dominion over corporation with respect to transaction at issue, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured party seeking to pierce the veil.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Pleading. Union and trust funds demonstrated good cause to amend complaint seeking employer's contributions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Premier Therapy, LLC v. Childs
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Seventh District, Columbiana County.
Headnote: There are three mandatory elements to pierce the corporate veil, including (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) the control by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud, an illegal act, or a similarly unlawful act, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Issue of whether guarantor of loan for purchasers of nursing home was alter ego for home such that corporate veil could be pierced was question for jury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Tatung Company, Ltd. v. Shu Tze Hsu
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under California law, courts apply the alter ego doctrine when the corporate form is used to perpetrate a fraud, circumvent a statute, or accomplish some other wrongful or inequitable purpose.
Document Preview: TORTS  RICO. Creditor suffered domestic injury to business or property, as required to recover for civil RICO violation against foreign debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Tatung Company, Ltd. v. Shu Tze Hsu
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California, Southern Division.
Headnote: The misdeeds required to establish specific manipulative conduct required for a court to find alter ego liability under California law need not be fraud; rather, the misconduct requirement turns on an inequitable result and not on actual fraud.
Document Preview: TORTS  RICO. Creditor suffered domestic injury to business or property, as required to recover for civil RICO violation against foreign debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Wolf Metals Inc. v. Rand Pacific Sales, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 4, California.
Headnote: Under the alter ego doctrine, when the corporate form is used to perpetrate a fraud, circumvent a statute, or accomplish some other wrongful or inequitable purpose, the courts will ignore the corporate entity and deem the corporation's acts to be those of the persons actually controlling the corporation, in most instances the equitable owners.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Officers and Directors. Court could not amend judgment to include buyer's president as judgment debtor after buyer's bankruptcy.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Skanska USA Bldg. Inc. v. Atlantic Yards B2 Owner, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Simple breach of contract, without more, does not constitute a fraud or wrong warranting the piercing of the corporate veil.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Liens. Statute governing liens under contracts for public improvements did not require posting of bond to guarantee performance.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Retail Service Systems, Inc. v. Mattress By Appointment, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In Ohio, to pierce the corporate veil and impose personal liability upon shareholders, it must be shown that: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Trade Secrets. District court had personal jurisdiction over a Florida limited liability and its sole owner and operator in misappropriation of trade secrets action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re American Ambulette & Ambulance Service, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. North Carolina, WILMINGTON DIVISION.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, in order to recover on alter ego theory, plaintiff must establish that corporate structure caused fraud or similar injustice, such that corporation is essentially a sham, existing for no other purpose than as vehicle for fraud.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Insiders could be entities for whose benefit challenged transfers were made.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: TLIG Maintenance Services, Inc. v. Fialkowski
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Alabama.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, a plaintiff must show fraud in asserting the corporate existence or must show that recognition of the corporate existence will result in injustice or inequitable consequences.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Individual who was not a shareholder could not be held individually liable in action against corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Energy Coal v. CITGO Petroleum Corporation
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Delaware courts only disregard the corporate form in the "exceptional case" where there is fraud or injustice through the misuse of the corporate form.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Choice of Law. Law of state of incorporation governed whether American company could be held liable for its Venezuelan affiliate's alleged breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Commonwealth Department of Environmental Protection v. Trainer Custom Chemical LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, it is appropriate to pierce the corporate veil through alter ego theory only where a corporation's affairs and personnel were manipulated to such an extent that it became nothing more than a sham used to disguise the alter ego's use of its assets for his own benefit in fraud of its creditors; evidence must show that the corporation's owners abused the legal separation of a corporation from its owners and used the corporation for illegitimate purposes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence that LLC was undercapitalized and did not comply with corporate formalities was insufficient to pierce corporate veil under alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Dieffenbacher
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: New York law requires a party seeking to pierce, or reverse pierce, a corporate veil to make a two-part showing: (1) that the owner exercised complete domination over corporation with respect to transaction at issue, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce the veil.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Contempt. Contempt sanction could not be calculated merely by multiplying daily fine by days of noncompliance.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Matter of Ritz
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, in the context of piercing the corporate veil, actual fraud is not equivalent to the tort of fraud; instead, in that context, "actual fraud" involves dishonesty of purpose or intent to deceive. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(b).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Establishing that a transfer is fraudulent under TUFTA's actual fraud prong is sufficient to satisfy the actual fraud requirement for veil-piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Crabtree
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Minnesota courts employ two-step analysis when determining whether corporate entity is alter ego of individual, under which they first consider the relationship between the corporation and the individual, focusing on factors such as a failure to observe corporate formalities, siphoning of corporate funds by the individual, absence of corporate records, and existence of corporation merely as a facade for the individual, and then consider nature of relationship between corporation and party seeking to pierce corporate veil and whether corporation has operated in a fraudulent or unjust manner toward that party.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Conversion of nonexempt assets to homestead triggers limitation on exemption rights.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: United States v. Executive Health Resources, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under the federal common law test for piercing the corporate veil, the situation must present an element of injustice or fundamental unfairness, but a number of the factors considered under the test can be sufficient to show such unfairness; no proof of actual fraud is required to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT  False Claims. Relator alleged nationwide scope of scheme with sufficient particularity in FCA action against physician advisor company.

Title: In re Stage Presence Incorporated
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Plaintiffs stated claim for liability based on alter ego or veil-piercing theory against individual who allegedly controlled debtor.

Title: Computer Reporting Service, LLC v. Lovejoy and Associates, LLC
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Ordinarily the "corporate veil" is pierced only under exceptional circumstances, for example, where the corporation is a mere shell, serving no legitimate purpose, and used primarily as an intermediary to perpetuate fraud or promote injustice.

Title: Fontana Builders, Inc. v. Assurance Co. of America
Court: Supreme Court of Wisconsin.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil is appropriate only when applying the corporate fiction would accomplish some fraudulent purpose, operate as a constructive fraud, or defeat some strong equitable claim.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Liability. Homeowners' policy did not apply to terminate coverage under builder's risk policy following fire.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Egan v. Tenet Health Care
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: The presumption of corporate separateness may be overcome by the operation of the doctrine of corporate disregard, which applies only when there is a compelling reason of equity to look beyond the corporate form for the purpose of defeating fraud or wrong, or for the remedying of injuries.

Title: Lim v. Miller Parking Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Proof of element of "fraud or wrong," as required under Michigan law in order to pierce corporate veil, is necessarily distinct from the separate, and additional, required showing that plaintiff would suffer some "unjust loss" if corporate veil were not pierced.

Title: Lim v. Miller Parking Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: In order to pierce corporate veil under Michigan law, plaintiff must prove some fraud or wrong going beyond merely an unjust loss to plaintiff if corporate veil is not pierced; plaintiff must establish that a controlling entity engaged in deliberate wrongful conduct that either was designed to or actually did produce injury to obligees of the instrumental entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate entities owned by members of same family were not alter egos, and veil that separated them could not be pierced.

Title: Lim v. Miller Parking Co.

Headnote: Under Michigan law, court sitting in equity may look through the veil of corporate structure, that is, pierce the corporate veil, in order to avoid fraud or injustice.

Title: Lim v. Miller Parking Co.

Title: Morello v. State

Title: SBC v. Cutler

Headnote: Under Michigan law, court sitting in equity may look through the veil of corporate structure, that is, pierce the corporate veil, in order to avoid fraud or injustice.

Title: Lim v. Miller Parking Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Prior to piercing corporate veil, Michigan court must determine whether the fraud or wrong that supports veil-piercing claim would cause plaintiff to suffer an unjust loss.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Transfers did not support piercing veil that separated debtor from related company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Agai v. Diontech Consulting, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Equity will intervene to pierce the corporate veil and permit the imposition of individual liability on owners for the obligations of their corporations in order to avoid fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence presented by judgment creditors warranted piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Innovative Biodefense, Inc. v. VSP Technologies, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: New York will disregard the corporate form when the corporation has been so dominated by an individual or another corporation and its separate identity so disregarded, that it primarily transacted the dominator's business rather than its own, and this domination was used to commit a fraud or other wrong that causes the plaintiff's loss.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Fact issues precluded summary judgment as to whether licensor materially breached sublicensing agreements concerning patented technology.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re McCauley
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Utah.
Headnote: Under Utah law, second prong of alter ego test, i.e., that observance of corporate form would sanction a fraud, promote injustice, or lead to inequitable result, is addressed to conscience of the court, and the circumstances under which it will be met will vary with each case; however, second prong of the test is not met simply because observing the integrity of corporation would in some way prevent creditor of controlling shareholder from quickly being made whole, or because existence of corporate form is inconvenient for creditor seeking to pursue shareholder's assets.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Estate could not be increased on veil-piercing theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Selfridge v. Jama
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil in Massachusetts and hold individual officers of corporation liable for corporation's acts, court must consider numerous factors, including: (1) common ownership; (2) pervasive control; (3) confused intermingling of business activity assets, or management; (4) thin capitalization; (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) no payment of dividends; (8) insolvency at the time of the litigated transaction; (9) siphoning away of corporate assets by the dominant shareholders; (10) nonfunctioning of officers and directors; (11) use of the corporation for transactions of the dominant shareholders; (12) use of the corporations in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Wrongful Discharge. Employer's conduct in terminating employee was not extreme or outrageous.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: M.J. v. Wisan
Court: Supreme Court of Utah.
Headnote: A claimant seeking to impose reverse-piercing liability on a corporate entity or trust must establish not only an abuse of the corporate form, but also that such abuse resulted in fraud or injustice, and that reverse piercing is necessary to avoid an injustice, or in other words, that the claimant lacks an adequate remedy at law.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Utah law allows reverse piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Jordan v. Maxfield & Oberton Holdings LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Mississippi, Northern Division.
Headnote: Mississippi law defines "alter ego" as a corporation used by an individual in conducting personal business, the result being that a court may impose liability on the individual by piercing the corporate veil when fraud has been perpetrated on someone dealing with the corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Jurisdiction. Company's jurisdictional contacts were imputed to founder in order to exercise personal jurisdiction under alter ego theory for claims of fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Jordan v. Maxfield & Oberton Holdings LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Mississippi, Northern Division.
Headnote: Under Mississippi law, in determining whether an individual is using a corporation as an alter ego, a court should consider a variety of kinds of evidence on whether the persons involved fail to behave as separate entities, as well as whether upholding corporate separateness would result in permitting a fraud to go forward; the alter ego doctrine has an unmistakable air of equity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Jurisdiction. Company's jurisdictional contacts were imputed to founder in order to exercise personal jurisdiction under alter ego theory for claims of fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Stenlund v. Marriott International, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Maryland law, although the courts will, in a proper case, disregard the corporate entity and deal with substance rather than form, as though a corporation did not exist, shareholders generally are not held individually liable for obligations of a corporation except where it is necessary to prevent fraud or enforce a paramount equity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Franchises and Dealerships. Hotel franchisor was not liable for hotel guest's injuries at on-site casino based on actual agency theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: First Natl. Bank of Omaha v. iBeam Solutions, L.L.C.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth District, Franklin County.
Headnote: The corporate form may be disregarded and individual shareholders held liable for wrongs committed by the corporation when (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Issue of whether to pierce corporate veil of public corporation was for jury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: McBeth v. Porges
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: A lawsuit's underlying cause of action, by itself, does not supply the necessary fraud or injustice under the test for piercing the corporate veil under an alter-ego theory under Delaware law.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. Sophisticated investor's reliance on any statements made by defendants prior to execution of offering papers was unreasonable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Aldmyr Systems, Inc. v. Friedman
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Under Maryland law, the doctrine of piercing the corporate veil applies only when necessary to prevent fraud or to enforce a paramount equity.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Jurisdiction. Under domestic relations exception, federal court did not have jurisdiction over corporations' claims against attorney who represented CEO's wife.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Accurso v. Infra-Red Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: The courts in Pennsylvania look at the following factors to determine whether a corporation is being operated as an alter ego of an individual defendant: (1) undercapitalization; (2) failure to adhere to corporate formalities; (3) substantial intermingling of corporate and personal affairs, and (4) use of the corporate form to perpetrate a fraud.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Sanctions. Spoliation sanctions would not be imposed on employee after he apparently deleted all of his personal e-mails.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Batoh v. McNeil-PPC, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Ordinarily, under Connecticut law, the corporate veil is pierced only under exceptional circumstances, for example, where the corporation is a mere shell, serving no legitimate purpose, and used primarily as an intermediary to perpetuate fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Evidence. Consumer's statements that he would not have taken medication if warnings had been more specific were not admissible under residual hearsay exception.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Batoh v. McNeil-PPC, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, the "instrumentality rule" for piercing the corporate veil requires, in any case but an express agency, proof of three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) that such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of the plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) that the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Evidence. Consumer's statements that he would not have taken medication if warnings had been more specific were not admissible under residual hearsay exception.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Overton v. Art Finance Partners LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: With respect to the second requirement for piercing the corporate veil under Delaware law, an overall element of injustice or unfairness, the injustice must consist of more than merely the tort or breach of contract that is the basis of the plaintiff's lawsuit; effectively, the corporation must be a sham and exist for no other purpose than as a vehicle for fraud.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Consignments. Art dealer's transfer of one painting to lender as collateral for a loan did not constitute a consignment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Tronox Incorporated
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, veil-piercing may be done only in the interest of justice, when such matters as fraud, contravention of law or contract, or public wrong are involved, or where equitable consideration among members of the corporation requires it.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Injunction. Injunction in settlement agreement barred tort claimants' claims against Chapter 11 debtors' former ultimate parent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Fairpoint Companies, LLC v. Vella
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: To state a veil piercing claim, the plaintiff is required to show that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.

Title: In re ES2 Sports & Leisure, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. North Carolina, Greensboro Division.
Headnote: Under North Carolina law, courts will disregard the corporate form, or pierce the corporate veil, and extend liability for corporate obligations beyond the confines of a corporation's separate entity, whenever necessary to prevent fraud or to achieve equity.

Title: In re ES2 Sports & Leisure, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. North Carolina, Greensboro Division.
Headnote: Under North Carolina law, in order to prevail under the instrumentality rule to pierce the corporate veil, a party must prove three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Debtor's parent company and its majority owner were liable for unjust enrichment for retaining security deposit rightfully payable to debtor.

Headnote: Courts consider the following factors when determining whether to pierce the corporate veil: (1) undercapitalization; (2) failure to adhere to corporate formalities; (3) substantial intermingling of corporate and personal affairs, and (4) use of the corporate form to perpetrate a fraud.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Judges. Recusal of court of common pleas judge who presided over action by contractor against developer was not warranted.

Headnote: Party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must establish that (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation with respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in the plaintiff's injury.

Title: In re Daebo International Shipping Co., Ltd.

Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil in federal maritime law, it must be established that one entity used the other to perpetrate a fraud or so dominated and disregarded the other entity's corporate form that the latter entity primarily transacted the former's business rather than its own corporate business.

Title: In re Daebo International Shipping Co., Ltd.

Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil in federal maritime law, the fraud must have been effected through the defendant's control or dominance over the alter ego.

Title: Kenkel v. Parker
Court: Supreme Court of Oklahoma.
Headnote: Ignoring the distinction between a corporation and its shareholders as separate entities is known as "piercing the corporate veil," and the distinction is not ignored unless it can be shown that there is a design or scheme to perpetrate a fraud or defeat public convenience, justify wrong, or defend crime.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Shareholders of bankrupt company that did not have workers' compensation insurance cannot generally be held personally liable for compensation awards.

Title: Franklin v. Daily Holdings, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil requires showing (1) that shareholders exercised complete domination over corporation with respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.

Title: Johnson v. Serenity Transportation, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: California courts generally require evidence of some bad-faith conduct to fulfill the second prong of alter ego liability, i.e., that failure to disregard the owner's and corporation's separate entities would result in fraud or injustice, and that bad faith must make it inequitable to recognize the corporate form.

Title: In re Anderson

Headnote: Under Louisiana law, traditional veil-piercing doctrines are generally limited to cases where the separate existence of the corporation has been abused and where the court finds that piercing the corporate veil is necessary to remedy fraud, illegality, or other inequitable conduct by the corporation's shareholders.

Title: Equitas Disability Advocates, LLC v. Bryant
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: In order to pierce the corporate veil under District of Columbia law, the plaintiff must show both that there is unity of interest between the owners and the corporate entity and that the owners used the corporate form to perpetuate fraud or wrong.

Title: Reynolds v. Lifewatch, Inc.

Headnote: Under New York law, a court may pierce the corporate veil where (1) the owner exercised complete domination over the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue, and (2) such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce the veil.

Title: Magnotti v. Crossroads Healthcare Management, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: To state a claim for individual liability under the alter ego doctrine, a plaintiff must plead (1) that the person exercises such dominion and control with respect to the transaction attacked that the corporation had no separate will of its own; and (2) that the domination and control was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which proximately caused his injuries.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Morrissey v. Krystopowicz
Court: Court of Appeals of New Mexico.
Headnote: Under certain circumstances, courts may exercise their equitable power to pierce the corporate veil, thereby requiring shareholders to answer for the corporation's liability; to do so, a court must find that (1) the corporation was operated not in a legitimate fashion to serve the valid goals and purposes of the corporation, but instead under the domination and control and for the purposes of some dominant party, (2) there is some form of moral culpability attributable to the shareholder, such as use of the corporation to perpetrate a fraud, and (3) there is some reasonable relationship between the injury suffered by the plaintiff and the actions of the defendant.

Title: Hawkeye Land Co. v. ITC Midwest LLC

Title: Pister v. State, Dept. of Revenue

Headnote: With regard to the first element for piercing the corporate veil under Washington law, namely, that the corporate form was used to violate or evade a duty, the court must find an abuse of the corporate form, which typically involves fraud, misrepresentation, or some form of manipulation of the corporation to the stockholder's benefit and creditor's detriment.

Title: In re Miller Parking Co., LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, an alter ego claim is not, by itself, a cause of action; rather, it is a doctrine which fastens liability on the individual who uses a corporation merely as an instrumentality to conduct his or her own personal business, with such liability arising from fraud or injustice perpetuated not on the corporation, but on third persons dealing with the corporation.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Bankruptcy trustee could not file claim in different case on behalf of estate's creditors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Simons v. Park City RV Resort, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Utah.
Headnote: The second part of the two-part test to entitle a movant to pierce the corporate veil, often called the "fairness requirement," requires the movant to show that observance of the corporate form would sanction a fraud, promote injustice, or condone an inequitable result.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Homeowner failed to show unity of interest and ownership between construction company and its president to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Nicks v. Nicks
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: In order to pierce the corporate veil, a party must satisfy three elements, including: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own, (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of a plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: FAMILY LAW - Spousal Support. Trial court did not abuse discretion, when determining alimony, by reducing wife's purportedly reasonable monthly expenses.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Gerritsen v. Warner Bros. Entertainment Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: The "inequitable result" prong of alter ego liability exists to address circumstances in which adherence to fiction of separate existence of corporation would, under the particular circumstances, sanction a fraud or promote injustice; bad faith is a critical factor in the analysis.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Author's amended complaint failed to allege plausible claims against entertainment corporation on successor-in-interest theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Northwest Cascade, Inc. v. Unique Const., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 2.
Headnote: Even where the corporate veil can be pierced for one purpose, but not another, a court continues to honor the corporation's separate identity except where doing so would perpetuate a fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Homestead. Shareholders did not have legal or equitable interest in corporation's property that would allow them to claim homestead exemption.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Janvey v. Libyan Investment Authority
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, piercing corporate veil requires showing that owner is using corporate entity as sham to perpetrate fraud, to avoid personal liability, avoid statute's effect, or in a few other exceptional situations.
Document Preview: INTERNATIONAL LAW  Foreign Sovereigns. District court had subject matter jurisdiction over receiver's action against Libyan Foreign Investment Company to recover Ponzi scheme proceeds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Wood
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Hawai‘i.
Headnote: Under Hawai'i law, court may disregard the separate entity status if recognition of the corporate fiction would bring about injustice and inequity or when there is evidence that the corporate fiction has been used to perpetrate a fraud or defeat a rightful claim. Haw. Rev. Stat. § 428-201.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debt for business loans was not excepted from debtor-wife's discharge under fraud discharge exception.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Green v. Ziegelman
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan.
Headnote: A court sitting in equity may look through the veil of corporate structure, that is, pierce the corporate veil, to avoid fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil was warranted to render principal personally liable for judgment obtained against corporate judgment debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Green v. Ziegelman
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan.
Headnote: When considering whether to disregard the separate existence of an artificial entity, a court must first examine the totality of the evidence surrounding the owner's use of an artificial entity and, in particular, the manner in which the entity was employed in the matter at issue; from this evidence, the trial court must determine whether the evidence establishes that the owner operated the entity as his or her alter ego, that is, as a sham or mere agent or instrumentality of his or her will and whether the manner of use effected a fraud or wrong on the complainant.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil was warranted to render principal personally liable for judgment obtained against corporate judgment debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Matthys v. Narconon Fresh Start
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Under Colorado law, the corporate entity may be disregarded, and the corporate veil may be pierced, if not doing so would defeat public convenience, justify wrong, or protect fraud.
Document Preview: TORTS  Emotional Distress. Alleged conduct of operator of substance abuse treatment facility was outrageous.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Commonwealth Land Title Insurance Company v. Miceli
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, DIVISION ONE.
Headnote: Actions to pierce the corporate veil rest on an equitable doctrine used by courts to look past the corporate form and impose liability upon those who control the corporation, be they individuals or other corporations, when they create or use the corporate form to accomplish a fraud, injustice, or some unlawful purpose.
Document Preview: INSURANCE  Title. Res judicata barred title insurer's fraud and negligence claims against home builder that misrepresented that subcontractors had been paid.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Commonwealth Land Title Insurance Company v. Miceli
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, DIVISION ONE.
Headnote: A court will disregard the corporate form and hold the corporate owners or officers liable if three elements are met: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) such control must have been used by the corporation to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: INSURANCE  Title. Res judicata barred title insurer's fraud and negligence claims against home builder that misrepresented that subcontractors had been paid.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Commonwealth Land Title Insurance Company v. Miceli
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, DIVISION ONE.
Headnote: Proof of the "fraud or wrong" element of piercing the corporate veil may be met where the defendant uses control of a corporation to perpetrate the violation of a positive legal duty.
Document Preview: INSURANCE  Title. Res judicata barred title insurer's fraud and negligence claims against home builder that misrepresented that subcontractors had been paid.

Title: Commonwealth Land Title Insurance Company v. Miceli
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, DIVISION ONE.
Headnote: The "fraud or wrong" element of piercing the corporate veil is met where the defendant uses control of a corporation to perpetrate a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of a plaintiff's legal rights.
Document Preview: INSURANCE  Title. Res judicata barred title insurer's fraud and negligence claims against home builder that misrepresented that subcontractors had been paid.

Title: In re Carrano

Headnote: Under Connecticut law, the corporate veil is pierced only under exceptional circumstances where the corporation is a mere shell, serving no legitimate purpose, and used primarily as an intermediary to perpetuate fraud or promote injustice.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Carrano
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, to pierce the corporate veil pursuant to the "instrumentality rule" requires, in any case but an express agency, proof of three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) that such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of the plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) that the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debt for overpayment of rent fell within the discharge exception for debts obtained through embezzlement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Sebago v. Boston Cab Dispatch, Inc.
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Suffolk.
Headnote: Disregard of the corporate form requires an analysis of the following factors: (1) common ownership; (2) pervasive control; (3) confused intermingling of business assets; (4) thin capitalization; (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) no payment of dividends; (8) insolvency at the time of the litigated transaction; (9) siphoning away of corporation's funds by dominant shareholder; (10) nonfunctioning of officers and directors; (11) use of the corporation for transactions of the dominant shareholders; and (12) use of the corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Independent Contractors. Taxicab drivers did not provide services to cab companies, as required for independent contractor statute to apply.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: AngioScore, Inc. v. TriReme Medical, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, when the corporate form is used to perpetrate a fraud, circumvent a statute, or accomplish some other wrongful or inequitable purpose, courts will apply the alter ego theory of liability to ignore the corporate entity and to deem the corporation's acts to be those of the persons or organizations actually controlling the corporation, in most instances the equitable owners.
Document Preview: PATENTS  Jurisdiction. In suit for patent infringement and state-law claims related to development of competing device, court properly exercised supplemental jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Lothrop v. North American Air Charter, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, courts considering whether to set aside corporate formalities consider twelve factors: (1) common ownership; (2) pervasive control; (3) confused intermingling of business assets; (4) thin capitalization; (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) no payment of dividends; (8) insolvency at the time of the litigated transaction; (9) siphoning away of corporation's funds by dominant shareholder; (10) nonfunctioning of officers and directors; (11) use of the corporation for transactions of the dominant shareholders; and (12) use of the corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. District court could not exercise personal jurisdiction over defendant under alter-ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Deschepper v. Midwest Wine and Spirits, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil under Illinois law: (1) there must be such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist, and (2) adhering to the fiction of a separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud, promote injustice, or promote inequitable consequences.

Headnote: In order for moving party to prevail on veil-piercing claim under New York law, party's evidence must show that individual used his control over corporation to commit a wrongful or unjust act specifically directed at moving party.

Title: In re Bull

Title: In re Bull
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Jacksonville Division.
Headnote: Under Florida's veil-piercing law, corporate creditor may pursue claim against corporation's shareholder only where: (1) the shareholder dominated and controlled corporation to such an extent that shareholder was, in fact, the alter ego of corporation; (2) the corporate form was used fraudulently or for an improper purpose; and (3) the fraudulent or improper use of corporation caused injury to the creditor seeking to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Corporate creditor had no veil-piercing claim in individual Chapter 11 case.

Title: In re Bull
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Jacksonville Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, courts are permitted to disregard corporate form and to pierce corporate veil only in the most extraordinary cases; simply stated, veil piercing is equitable remedy that is used to prevent fraudulent or improper use of corporate form from injuring the party seeking to pierce corporate veil.

Title: In re Bull

Headnote: Unlike veil piercing, which may be predicated either upon a showing of fraud or upon complete control by dominating corporation that leads to a wrong against third parties, substantive consolidation has narrower focus, i.e., the equitable treatment of all creditors.

Title: In re Mihalatos
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Veil piercing and alter ego doctrines are logically and legally distinct under New York law; while veil piercing will always require proof of a wrong or fraud as well as injury, an alter ego finding, in and of itself, does not confirm the commission of a wrong or the occurrence of an injury, but merely recognizes what was a preexisting fact, that, at the time of the relevant transaction, the controlling principal and corporation were in actuality one and the same, the former inseparable from the latter.

Title: TIAA Global Investments, LLC v. One Astoria Square LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Corporate veil of a business entity may be pierced where a plaintiff sufficiently states that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud of wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.

Title: Fed. Ins. Co. v. Fredericks

Title: Powertrain, Inc. v. Ma

Headnote: Under Mississippi law, "alter ego" is defined as a corporation used by an individual in conducting personal business, the result being that a court may impose liability on the individual by piercing the corporate veil when fraud has been perpetrated on someone dealing with the corporation.

Title: Powertrain, Inc. v. Ma
