Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: AZTE, Inc. v. Auto Collection, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: A plaintiff seeking to pierce the corporate veil must demonstrate that a court in equity should intervene because the owners of the corporation exercised complete domination over it in the transaction at issue and, in doing so, abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form, thereby perpetrating a wrong that resulted in injury to the plaintiff.

Title: Bash v. Textron Financial Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, corporate form may be disregarded and individual shareholders held liable for corporate misdeeds when: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.

Title: U.S. v. Cochran

Headnote: In extraordinary cases, such as the corporate form being used for wrongful purposes, courts will pierce the corporate veil and disregard the corporate entity.

Title: Lodges at Bear Hollow Condominium Homeowners Ass'n, Inc. v. Bear Hollow Restoration, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Utah.
Headnote: The "Norman test" is a two-part test to determine when a party in a breach of contract action against a corporation may pierce the corporate veil and obtain judgment against individual shareholders; the first part of the test, often called the "formalities requirement", requires the movant to show such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist, and the second part of the test, often called the "fairness requirement", requires the movant to show that observance of the corporate form would sanction a fraud, promote injustice, or condone an inequitable result.

Headnote: Pursuant to Ohio law, there is a three-prong test for the Court to determine whether veil piercing is proper in a particular case, and the court may disregard the corporate form and hold individual shareholders liable for corporate misdeeds if: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.

Title: Toumazou v. Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under test for determining whether corporate entity is alter ego of person or corporation in control, as required to pierce the corporate veil, courts in the District of Columbia generally inquire as to whether corporate formalities have been observed, whether there has been commingling of corporate and shareholder funds, staff, and property, whether a single shareholder dominates the corporation, whether the corporation is adequately capitalized, and, especially, whether the corporate form has been used to effectuate a fraud.

Title: Nutt v. Kees
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Arkansas, Jonesboro Division.
Headnote: A basis for piercing the corporate veil exists under the alter ego doctrine, if the corporation: (1) is controlled by another to the extent that it has independent existence in form only, and (2) is used as a subterfuge to defeat public convenience, to justify wrong, or to perpetuate a fraud.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Nursing home operator was liable under successor theory for previous owner's ERISA violations.

Title: In re McCauley
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Utah.
Headnote: To invoke the alter ego doctrine under Utah law, there must be a concurrence of two circumstances: (1) there must be such a unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist, viz., the corporation is, in fact, the alter ego of one or a few individuals; and (2) the observance of the corporate form would sanction a fraud, promote injustice, or an inequitable result would follow.

Title: John Knox Village v. Fortis Const. Co., LLC
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: Courts will disregard the corporate entity and hold corporate owners liable for the corporation's wrongful acts if the following three elements are established: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) such control must have been used by the corporation to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Substantial evidence supported piercing corporate veil to hold general contractor's owners individually liable for fraud.

Title: Hammett v. Atcheson

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Winderting Investments, LLC v. Furnell
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Second District.
Headnote: To justify the issuance of a rule directing individual stockholders to show cause why they should not be held personally accountable for the corporation's debts, there should be a preliminary showing that the corporation is in actuality the alter ego of the stockholders and that it was organized or after organization was employed by the stockholders for fraudulent or misleading purposes, or in some fashion that the corporate property was converted or the corporate assets depleted for the personal benefit of the individual stockholders, or that the corporate structure was not bona fidely established or, in general, that property belonging to the corporation can be traced into the hands of the stockholders.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Discovery. Judgment creditors failed to show that nonparty was alter ego of judgment creditor and, thus, were not entitled to financial discovery from nonparty.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Soule v. High Rock Holding, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: Nevada courts apply the alter ego doctrine where the following requirements are met: (1) the corporation must be influenced and governed by the person asserted to be its alter ego, (2) there must be such unity of interest and ownership that one is inseparable from the other, and (3) the facts must be such that adherence to the fiction of separate entity would, under the circumstances, sanction a fraud or promote injustice; it is not necessary that the plaintiff prove actual fraud, rather, it is enough if the recognition of the two entities as separate would result in an injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Judgment. The Bankruptcy Court abused its discretion in denying a creditor's request for additional time for discovery under summary judgment rule.

Title: A.V.E.L.A., Inc. v. Estate of Monroe
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: New York law allows the corporate veil to be pierced either when there is fraud or when the corporation has been used as an alter ego.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Pleading. Neither undue delay, undue prejudice, nor futility precluded granting of a motion to amend a counterclaim.

Title: U.S. v. Federal Resources Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Idaho.
Headnote: Under Idaho law, the corporate veil may be pierced when (1) there is such a unity of interest and ownership that the individuality of such corporation and such person has ceased and (2) it appears from the facts that the observance of the fiction of separate existence would, under the circumstances, sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Response action taken by government under CERCLA was consistent with national contingency plan.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Ritz
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, alter ego or other similar theories may be used to pierce the corporate veil in breach of contract action and to hold shareholder personally liable for the breach only if: (1) actual fraud is shown, and (2) it was perpetrated primarily for direct personal benefit of shareholder. V.T.C.A., Business Organizations Code § 21.223.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Fraud-based dischargeability exception requires showing of misrepresentation.

Title: In re Ritz
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Actual fraud, of kind required under Texas law to pierce corporate veil and to holds shareholder personally liable for breach of corporate contract, is the misrepresentation of material fact with the intention to induce action or inaction, and reliance on that misrepresentation by person who, as result of such reliance, suffers injury. V.T.C.A., Business Organizations Code § 21.223.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Fraud-based dischargeability exception requires showing of misrepresentation.

Title: In re Ritz
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: If obligee shows that shareholder used corporation to perpetrate fraud on obligee for shareholder's direct personal benefit, then shareholder is liable under Texas law on alter ego or veil-piercing theory. V.T.C.A., Business Organizations Code § 21.223.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Fraud-based dischargeability exception requires showing of misrepresentation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Ritz
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, courts may deduce fraudulent intent from all the facts and circumstances, and generally look at totality of shareholder's actions to determine whether he or she committed an actual fraud, of kind required in order to pierce corporate veil and to hold shareholder personally liable for breach of corporate contract. V.T.C.A., Business Organizations Code § 21.223.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Fraud-based dischargeability exception requires showing of misrepresentation.

Title: In re Ritz
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: "Actual fraud," of kind required under Texas law in order to pierce corporate veil and to hold shareholder personally liable for breach of corporate contract, is not equivalent to tort of fraud. V.T.C.A., Business Organizations Code § 21.223.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Fraud-based dischargeability exception requires showing of misrepresentation.

Title: Ferrara v. Smithtown Trucking Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: In determining alter ego status, courts typically look to the following factors: (1) absence of formalities which are part and parcel of normal corporate existence, i.e., issuance of stock, election of directors, keeping of corporate records, etc., (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) personal use of corporate funds, and (4) perpetration of fraud by means of corporate vehicle.

Title: U.S. v. Boyce
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: California law recognizes alter ego liability where two conditions are met: (1) there is such a unity of interest and ownership that the individuality, or separateness, of said person and corporation has ceased, and (2) adherence to the fiction of the separate existence of the corporation would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Collection. Transferee was nominee of taxpayer, for purposes of enforcing federal tax lien.

Title: Al Rushaid v. National Oilwell Varco, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, the limitation on liability afforded by the corporate structure can be ignored only when the corporate form has been used as part of a basically unfair device to achieve an inequitable result, such as when the corporate structure has been abused to perpetuate a fraud, evade an existing obligation, achieve or perpetuate a monopoly, circumvent a statute, protect a crime, or justify wrong.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Arbitration. Actions of related co-defendants could not be attributed to one defendant for purposes of assessing waiver of a right to arbitrate.

Title: Ralls Corp. v. Huerfano River Wind, LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Newnan Division.
Headnote: Under Georgia law, piercing the corporate veil is used to remedy injustices which arise where a party has over extended his privilege in the use of a corporate entity in order to defeat justice, perpetuate fraud or to evade contractual or tort responsibility.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Ralls Corp. v. Huerfano River Wind, LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Newnan Division.
Headnote: To show that the shareholders disregarded the corporate entity and made it a mere instrumentality for the transaction of their own affairs, as required to prevail under alter-ego theory of liability under Georgia law, the plaintiff must generally establish evidence of fraud, abuse of the corporate form, commingling of assets or corporate insolvency at the time of the transaction.

Title: William v. AES Corp.

Headnote: The corporate veil may be pierced when the corporate form would otherwise be misused to accomplish certain wrongful purposes, most notably fraud, on the shareholder's behalf.

Title: William v. AES Corp.

Headnote: Under Virginia law, a court can pierce the corporate veil only upon showing that: (1) the corporation was the alter ego, alias, stooge, or dummy of the other entity, and (2) the corporation was a device or sham used to disguise wrongs, obscure fraud, or conceal crime.

Title: William v. AES Corp.

Headnote: Under Delaware law, to pierce the corporate veil on an alter ego theory, the corporation must be a sham and exist for no other purpose than as a vehicle for fraud.

Title: Glenn v. TPI Petroleum, Inc.

Headnote: In order to pierce the corporate veil, the corporate entity must be a mere instrumentality of another entity or individual, the corporate entity must be used to commit a fraud or wrong, and there must have been an unjust loss or injury to the plaintiff.

Title: In re Lehmann

Title: In re Chu

Headnote: Under Hawaii law, courts may disregard the corporate form and pierce corporate veil when recognition of corporation fiction would bring about injustice and inequity, or when there is evidence that corporate fiction has been used to perpetrate fraud or defeat a rightful claim.

Title: Nieto-Vincenty v. Valledor
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Corporate veil may be pierced pursuant to Puerto Rico law where recognizing the corporate form would (1) sanction a fraud; (2) promote an injustice; (3) evade statutory obligations; (4) violate public policy; (5) result in inequity; or (6) cover up fraudulent or criminal activity. 14 L.P.R.A. § 3501 et seq.

Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.

Title: Landstar Inway Inc. v. Samrow

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Landstar Inway Inc. v. Samrow
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 2.
Headnote: Normally a corporate entity will be regarded unless to do so would help accomplish the breach of a duty owing to a person who has dealt with the corporation; in exceptional cases, however, when a natural or artificial person sought to be held liable has so conducted himself or itself with respect to the person seeking relief that not to enforce the remedy for breach against that person would aid in the perpetration of a wrong as, for example, accomplishing a fraud, the corporate entity will be disregarded to prevent such a result.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Heightened pleading requirement for fraud did not apply to claim that fraud by LLC member warranted disregard of LLC form.

Title: VFS Financing, Inc. v. Falcon Fifty LLC

Title: VFS Financing, Inc. v. Falcon Fifty LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: The injustice or unfairness element of the Delaware test for piercing the corporate veil under an alter-ego theory requires demonstrating a fraud or similar injustice in the use of the corporate form; the underlying cause of action, at least by itself, does not supply the necessary fraud or injustice.

Title: Solnes v. Wallis & Wallis, P.A.

Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil under Florida law, a plaintiff must allege that (1) the shareholder dominated and controlled the corporation to such an extent that the corporation's independent existence was in fact non-existent and the shareholders were in fact alter egos of the corporation; (2) the corporate form must have been used fraudulently or for an improper purpose; and (3) the fraudulent or improper use of the corporate form caused injury to the claimant.

Title: Green v. Freeman
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: To hold a defendant personally liable for the actions of a corporation, a plaintiff must present evidence of three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of a plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Officers and Directors. Chairperson's delegation of authority to her son did not create agency relationship between herself personally and her son.

Title: A&M Global Management Corp. v. Northtown Urology Associates, P.C.

Title: Lopes v. JetsetDC, LLC

Title: In re Dott Acquisition, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, a court may find that one entity is the alter ego of another and pierce the corporate veil upon proof of three elements: (1) the corporate entity must be a mere instrumentality of another, (2) the corporate entity must be used to commit a fraud or wrong, and (3) there must have been an unjust loss or injury to the plaintiff.

Title: Country Contractors, Inc. v. A Westside Storage of Indianapolis, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: A party seeking to pierce the corporate veil may only recover from a shareholder if the party proves by a preponderance of the evidence that: (1) the corporate form was so ignored, controlled or manipulated that it was merely the instrumentality of another, and (2) that the misuse of the corporate form would constitute a fraud or promote injustice. West's A.I.C. 23–1–26–3(b).

Title: Country Contractors, Inc. v. A Westside Storage of Indianapolis, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: In order for the corporate veil to be pierced, the fraud or injustice alleged by the party seeking to pierce the veil must be caused by, or result from, misuse of the corporate form. West's A.I.C. 23–1–26–3(b).

Title: Seghers v. LaPlace Equipment Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Before the corporate entity is disregarded on the basis it is simply the alter ego of the member, proof of fraud or deceit is usually required; the corporate entity may also be disregarded when the individualities of the corporation and member cease to exist.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Dog House Investments, LLC v. Teal Properties, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee, Western Section, at Nashville.
Headnote: When determining whether piercing the corporate veil is appropriate, the court must consider whether the corporate entity has been used to work a fraud or injustice in contravention of public policy and also: (1) whether there was a failure to collect paid in capital; (2) whether the corporation was grossly undercapitalized; (3) the nonissuance of stock certificates; (4) the sole ownership of stock by one individual; (5) the use of the same office or business location; (6) the employment of the same employees or attorneys; (7) the use of the corporation as an instrumentality or business conduit for an individual or another corporation; (8) the diversion of corporate assets by or to a stockholder or other entity to the detriment of creditors, or the manipulation of assets and liabilities in another; (9) the use of the corporation as a subterfuge in illegal transactions; (10) the formation and use of the corporation to transfer to it the existing liability of another person or entity; and (11) the failure to maintain arms length relationships among related entities.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Landlord and Tenant. Lease provision delineating landlord's obligations for damage to premises from fire or other cause encompassed flood damage.

Title: Rock Ivy Holding, LLC v. RC Properties, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee.
Headnote: When applicable, factors to be considered in determining whether to disregard the corporate veil include not only whether the entity has been used to work a fraud or injustice in contravention of public policy, but also: (1) whether there was a failure to collect paid in capital; (2) whether the corporation was grossly undercapitalized; (3) the nonissuance of stock certificates; (4) the sole ownership of stock by one individual; (5) the use of the same office or business location; (6) the employment of the same employees or attorneys; (7) the use of the corporation as an instrumentality or business conduit for an individual or another corporation; (8) the diversion of corporate assets by or to a stockholder or other entity to the detriment of creditors, or the manipulation of assets and liabilities in another; (9) the use of the corporation as a subterfuge in illegal transactions; (10) the formation and use of the corporation to transfer to it the existing liability of another person or entity; and (11) the failure to maintain arms length relationships among related entities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. President of LLC did not violate his duty of loyalty in seeking to sell LLC's property.

Title: Snapp v. Castlebrook Builders, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Third District, Shelby County.
Headnote: The "veil" of the corporation can be "pierced" and individual shareholders held liable for corporate misdeeds in exceptional circumstances when the shareholders use the corporation for criminal or fraudulent purposes to the detriment of a third party; in those exceptional circumstances, the courts treat the corporation as a mere "alter ego" of the shareholder, thereby rendering the shareholder liable for the obligations of the corporation.

Title: Snapp v. Castlebrook Builders, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Third District, Shelby County.
Headnote: In order to disregard the corporate form and hold an individual shareholder liable for wrongs committed by the corporation, the plaintiff must demonstrate all three of the following: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) defendant shareholder exercised control over the corporation in such a manner as to commit fraud, an illegal act, or a similarly unlawful act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Green v. Freeman
Court: Supreme Court of North Carolina.
Headnote: After the fact finder determines that the corporate veil should be pierced, the next inquiry is whether a noncorporate defendant may be held liable for her personal actions as an officer or director, and to succeed in this inquiry, plaintiffs must present evidence of three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; and (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of a plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.

Headnote: Under Wisconsin law, the alter ego doctrine requires proof of: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.

Title: Michaels v. Banks

Headnote: A corporations' owner may be held liable where it is established that: (1) the owner exercised complete domination over the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue, such that it is an alter ego of the corporation, and (2) such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce the veil.

Title: Michaels v. Banks
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: A showing of complete control, standing alone, is insufficient to pierce the corporate veil; rather, that control exercised by the shareholder must have been used to perpetrate fraud or other wrong that resulted in unjust loss or injury.

Title: Estate of Hurst ex rel. Cherry v. Moorehead I, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: To support an attack on a separate corporate entity under the instrumentality rule, a party must satisfy three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.

Title: In re Adler
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, veil-piercing and alter ego doctrines are logically and legally distinguishable: while veil-piercing always requires proof of some wrong or fraud as well as injury, alter ego finding formally recognizes what was a preexisting fact, that at time of relevant transaction, one or more controlling principals and one or more corporations were in actuality one and the same person, the former inseparable from the latter and its liability both personal and direct.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debtor failed to provide sufficient explanation for record-keeping lapses.

Title: Swan v. Board of Educ. of City of Chicago
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Illinois law permits piercing of the corporate veil when two separate prongs are met: (1) there must be such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist; and (2) circumstances must be such that adherence to the fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.

Title: Phillips v. Reed Group, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Colorado law, courts considering whether to pierce the corporate veil to impose liability on individual shareholders assess: (1) the extent to which the corporation is merely the alter ego of the shareholder; (2) whether justice requires piercing the corporate veil based on the fact that the corporate fiction was a means of perpetuating a fraud or defeating a rightful claim; and (3) whether an equitable result will be achieved by piercing the corporate veil.

Title: Phillips v. Reed Group, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil under Colorado law, plaintiff must show that: (1) the corporate entity is the alter ego of the shareholder; (2) justice requires the veil to be pierced because the corporate fiction was used to perpetrate a fraud or defeat a rightful claim and to shield a dominant shareholder's improprieties; and (3) an equitable result will be achieved by holding the shareholder personally liable for the acts of the business entity.

Title: In re Checiek
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, TAMPA DIVISION.
Headnote: Under Florida law, veil piercing is most commonly used by a creditor seeking to pursue a corporation's shareholder where (1) the corporate shareholder dominated and controlled the corporation to such an extent that the shareholder was, in fact, the alter ego of the corporation, (2) the corporate form was used fraudulently or for an improper purpose, and (3) the fraudulent or improper use of the corporation caused injury to the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil.

Title: Beltran v. Vincent P. Miraglia, M.D., P.A.

Title: Oehme, van Sweden & Associates, Inc. v. Maypaul Trading & Services Ltd.

Headnote: Under District of Columbia law, a party seeking to pierce the corporate veil and thereby establish that a corporation is an alter ego of an individual must show by affirmative evidence: (1) unity of ownership and interest between the corporation and the individual, and (2) use of the corporate form to perpetrate fraud or wrong.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Arbitration. Nonsignatory to architectural contract was bound to arbitrate dispute.

Title: Howell Contractors, Inc. v. Berling
Court: Court of Appeals of Kentucky.
Headnote: In order to pierce the corporate veil under Kentucky law, two elements must be met: (1) the loss of corporate or entity separateness, as established by analysis of the eleven factors listed in Inter–Tel Techs., Inc. v. Linn Station Props., LLC; and (2) the sanctioning of fraud or promoting injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. LLC's failure to pay an entity debt did not rise to the level of fraud, illegality, or unlawfulness necessary to pierce the entity veil.

Title: Michaels v. Banks
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Corporate veil may be pierced where it is established that (1) the owner exercised complete domination over the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue, and (2) such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce the veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Triable fact issues regarding piercing of the corporate veil precluded summary judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Michaels v. Banks
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: While there is a presumption that the corporate entity and not its shareholders is held liable for corporate acts, the corporate veil may be pierced and shareholders held liable either upon a showing of fraud or upon complete control by the dominating entity that leads to a wrong against third parties, and thus, a showing of complete control, that is, a shareholder acting as the alter ego of the corporation, standing alone, is insufficient to pierce the corporate veil, but rather, that control must have been used to perpetrate fraud or other wrong that resulted in unjust loss or injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Triable fact issues regarding piercing of the corporate veil precluded summary judgment.

Title: Marnavi S.p.A. v. Keehan
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, disregard of the corporate entity under the alter ego theory is appropriate only in exceptional circumstances; in particular, the law requires that fraud or injustice be found in the defendants' use of the corporate form.

Title: Shearrow v. Easton Enterprises, LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois.
Headnote: Second prong of the showing a Title VII plaintiff must make to pierce the corporate veil of an affiliate corporation, i.e., that circumstances are such that adherence to the fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice, requires something less than an affirmative showing of fraud, but something more than the mere prospect of an unsatisfied judgment; plaintiff must show that a party would be unjustly enriched, a parent corporation that caused a subsidiary's liabilities and its inability to pay for them would escape those liabilities, or an intentional scheme to squirrel assets into a liability-free corporation while heaping liabilities upon an asset-free corporation would be successful. Civil Rights Act of 1964, §§ 703(a), 704(a), 42 U.S.C.A. §§ 2000e–2(a), 2000e–3(a).
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Employer's corporate affiliates were not proper defendants in a former employee's Title VII action.

Title: In re Steffner
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Tennessee.
Headnote: Under Tennessee law, factors to be considered in determining whether to disregard corporate veil include not only whether entity has been used to work a fraud or injustice in contravention of public policy, but also (1) whether there was failure to collect paid in capital, (2) whether corporation was grossly undercapitalized, (3) nonissuance of stock certificates, (4) sole ownership of stock by one individual, (5) use of same office or business location, (6) employment of same employees or attorneys, (7) use of corporation as instrumentality or business conduit for individual or another corporation, (8) diversion of corporate assets by or to stockholder or other entity to detriment of creditors, or manipulation of assets and liabilities in another, (9) use of corporation as subterfuge in illegal transactions, (10) formation and use of corporation to transfer to it existing liability of another person or entity, and (11) failure to maintain arms-length relationships among related entities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Piercing of corporate veil of limited liability company was not warranted under Tennessee law

Title: Jones & Trevor Marketing, Inc. v. Lowry

Title: Wachovia Securities, LLC v. Banco Panamericano, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, a finding that adhering to the separate identities of the corporation and its owners would sanction a fraud or promote injustice, as required to pierce the corporate veil, requires something less than an affirmative showing of fraud, but something more than the mere prospect of an unsatisfied judgment.

Title: Commissioner of Environmental Protection v. State Five Indus. Park, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: The law permits the incorporation of businesses for the very purpose of isolating liabilities among separate entities, and thus the corporate veil is pierced only under exceptional circumstances, for example, where the corporation is a mere shell, serving no legitimate purpose, and used primarily as an intermediary to perpetuate fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Imposition of reverse veil piercing was unwarranted under instrumentality rule.

Title: CBR Event Decorators, Inc. v. Gates

Headnote: Courts are reluctant to disregard corporate identity and do so only where the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil can establish that the corporate form has been misused and the result of that misuse is fraud or injustice.

Title: CBR Event Decorators, Inc. v. Gates
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: The fraud or injustice alleged by a party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must be caused by, or result from, misuse of the corporate form.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Lack of causal connection between misuse of corporate form and alleged fraud or injustice precluded shareholder liability.

Title: Restaurant of Hattiesburg, LLC v. Hotel & Restaurant Supply, Inc.

Title: Estate of Bishop v. Mulholland

Title: In re Ritz

Headnote: Although, previously, Texas law allowed for the corporate veil to be pierced under three expansive categories, namely, where the corporation is the alter ego of its owners and/or shareholders, where the corporation is used for illegal purposes, and where the corporation is used as a sham to perpetrate a fraud, a litigant seeking to pierce the corporate veil for breach of contract now must also prove that the defendant shareholder caused the corporation to be used for the purpose of perpetrating and did perpetrate an actual fraud on the obligee primarily for the direct personal benefit of the shareholder. Title: Weinstein v. eBay, Inc.

Headnote: Under New York law, piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: ANTITRUST - Professional Sports. Professional baseball team's website did not violate New York law by providing link to a ticket reseller's website.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Martin v. Spring Break 83 Production, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, at least one of four general circumstances must be satisfied before a court will pierce the corporate veil: (1) a court will pierce the corporate veil if a third party is a victim of fraud, breach of professional duty, negligence, or another wrongful act by the individual member of the limited liability company (LLC); (2) a court will pierce the corporate veil if the members of the LLC use the corporate form to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, protect fraud, or defend crime; (3) a court will pierce the corporate veil if adherence to the corporate form would clearly result in inequity; and (4) a court will pierce the corporate veil if it finds evidence of misuse of corporate privilege.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Hours and Wages. Nonsignatory film producer and its individual employees were not employers under the FLSA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: James v. Loran Realty V Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Actions of corporation's president were not for purpose of leaving corporation judgment proof, and thus piercing of corporate veil was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Hottenstein v. City of Seal Isle City
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Under New Jersey law, a corporation is a separate entity from its shareholders, and that a primary reason for incorporation is the insulation of shareholders from the liabilities of the corporate enterprise; accordingly, except in cases of fraud, injustice, or the like, courts will not pierce a corporate veil.
Document Preview: TORTS - Dram Shop. Negligence claims against bars were barred by the New Jersey Dram Shop Act's exclusive remedy provision.

Headnote: Under California law, the alter ego doctrine prevents individuals or other corporations from misusing the corporate laws by the device of a sham corporate entity formed for the purpose of committing fraud or other misdeeds.

Title: DeRosa v. Accredited Home Lenders, Inc.
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division.
Headnote: The purpose of the doctrine of piercing the corporate veil is to prevent an independent corporation from being used to defeat the ends of justice, to perpetrate fraud, to accomplish a crime, or otherwise to evade the law.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Layoffs. In determining whether parent and affiliated companies may be held liable under state WARN Act, courts must apply 5-factor test.

Title: Michnovez v. Blair, LLC

Headnote: Under New Hampshire law, corporate veil piercing is appropriate where a shareholder creates a false appearance which causes a reasonable creditor to misapprehend the worth of the corporate obligor.

Title: In re Arnette
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, there are three broad categories of grounds on which a court may pierce the corporate veil: (1) the corporation is the alter ego of its owners and/or shareholders, (2) the corporation is used for illegal purposes, and (3) the corporation is used as a sham to perpetrate a fraud.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debtor's personal liability for fraud committed against investor by his companies fell within fraud discharge exception.

Title: In re Arnette
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, where actual fraud primarily for the benefit of the perpetrating shareholder or shareholders can be shown, the various doctrines for disregarding the corporate entity, including alter ego and a sham to perpetrate a fraud, are available under statute setting forth additional requirements for piercing the corporate veil in cases based on claims for breach of contract. V.T.C.A., Business Organizations Code § 21.223.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debtor's personal liability for fraud committed against investor by his companies fell within fraud discharge exception.

Title: In re Arnette

Headnote: Actual fraud required under Texas statute imposing additional requirements for piercing the corporate veil in cases based on claims for breach of contract simply requires proof of dishonesty of purpose or intent to deceive. V.T.C.A., Business Organizations Code § 21.223.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debtor's personal liability for fraud committed against investor by his companies fell within fraud discharge exception.

Title: Leek v. Cooper
Court: Court of Appeal, Third District, California.
Headnote: Several factors are to be considered in applying the alter ego doctrine; among them are commingling of funds and other assets, failure to segregate funds of the separate entities, and the unauthorized diversion of corporate funds or assets to other than corporate uses, the treatment by an individual of the assets of the corporation as his own, the failure to obtain authority to issue stock or to subscribe to or issue the same, the holding out by an individual that he is personally liable for the debts of the corporation, the failure to maintain minutes or adequate corporate records, sole ownership of all of the stock in a corporation by one individual or the members of a family, the failure to adequately capitalize a corporation, the total absence of corporate assets, and undercapitalization, the use of a corporation as a mere shell, instrumentality or conduit for a single venture or the business of an individual or another corporation, the concealment and misrepresentation of the identity of the responsible ownership, management and financial interest, or concealment of personal business activities, the disregard of legal formalities and the failure to maintain arm's length relationships among related entities, the use of the corporate entity to procure labor, services or merchandise for another person or entity, the diversion of assets from a corporation by or to a stockholder or other person or entity, to the detriment of creditors, or the manipulation of assets and liabilities between entities so as to concentrate the assets in one and the liabilities in another, the contracting with another with intent to avoid performance by use of a corporate entity as a shield against personal liability, or the use of a corporation as a subterfuge of illegal transactions, and the formation and use of a corporation to transfer to it the existing liability of another person or entity.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Employer's Liability. Corporation's sole shareholder was not employees' employer for purposes of FEHA discrimination claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >

Title: Louisburg Bldg. & Development Co., L.L.C. v. Albright
Court: Court of Appeals of Kansas.
Headnote: A fraud or injustice committed by a corporation ordinarily will be remedied by the penalties that the law assesses against that corporation as a remedy; it is the corporation's inability or unwillingness to comply with those remedies that prompts disregarding the corporate entity.

Title: Wooley v. Lucksinger
Court: Supreme Court of Louisiana.
Headnote: Under the provisions of Texas veil piercing statute, a shareholder cannot be held liable for the actions of the corporation, or have the corporate veil pierced, on the basis that (1) the shareholder is the alter ego of the corporation, or (2) fraud of some sort occurred, unless the plaintiff demonstrates the shareholder caused the corporation to be used to perpetrate, and did perpetrate, an actual fraud on the plaintiff primarily for the shareholder's direct personal benefit. V.T.C.A., Business Organizations Code § 21.223.

Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, veil-piercing analysis has two elements: (1) owner exercised complete domination over corporation with respect to transaction at issue; and (2) such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong that injured party seeking to pierce veil.

Title: Colon v. Blades
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Under Puerto Rico law, where directors or officers use corporation to commit fraud, courts will "pierce corporate veil" and hold those officers or directors personally liable.

Title: Sullivan v. Sullivan
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: Equity will not allow a corporate veil to cover fraud or injustice, and to prevent such the corporate entity may be disregarded and the corporation and individual or individuals owning all of its stock and assets treated as identical.
Document Preview: FAMILY LAW - Attorney Fees. Award of appellate attorney fees was warranted as sanction for former husband's unsupported appeal from contempt order.

Title: Hamilton Partners, L.P. v. Englard
Court: Court of Chancery of Delaware.
Headnote: Delaware has a powerful interest of its own in preventing the entities that it charters from being used as vehicles for fraud; Delaware's legitimacy as a chartering jurisdiction depends on it.

Title: In re Jamuna Real Estate, LLC

Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, the corporate veil will be pierced on a showing of injustice, rather than fraud.

Title: Atateks Foreign Trade, Ltd. v. Private Label Sourcing, LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Veil piercing is warranted under New York law when an abuse of the corporate form occurs either through on-going fraudulent activities of a principal or a pronounced and intimate commingling of identities of the corporation and its principal or principals.

Title: Cassese v. Washington Mutual, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Washington law requires that the corporate form be disregarded only when to do otherwise would work a fraud upon third persons.

Title: A & B Bolt & Supply, Inc. v. Dawes
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: It is not unusual for a court in this country to disregard the corporate entity, or in synonymous terms pierce the corporate veil, when corporate form has been used to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, protect fraud, or defend crime; nevertheless, plaintiffs opposing summary judgment must state a factual basis in their petition upon which such a finding may be made and must put forth evidence at the hearing on the motion for summary judgment to survive dismissal.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Employee's business was not liable for employee's alleged breach of non-compete agreement, absent any allegation business was alter-ego of employee organized for purposes of circumventing agreement.

Title: Michiana Dairy Processors, LLC v. All Star Beverage, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Indiana, Hammond Division.
Headnote: Under Indiana law, party seeking to pierce corporate veil bears burden of establishing that corporation was so ignored, controlled or manipulated that it was merely instrumentality of another, and that misuse of corporate form would constitute fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Bottled water supplier's failure to perform barred its breach of contract claim.

Title: Breen v. Judge

Headnote: Ordinarily, the corporate veil is pierced only under exceptional circumstances, for example, where the corporation is a mere shell, serving no legitimate purpose, and used primarily as an intermediary to perpetuate fraud or promote injustice.

Title: Breen v. Judge

Headnote: The improper use of the corporate form is the key to the inquiry regarding whether to pierce the corporate veil, as courts will disregard legal fictions, including that of a separate corporate entity, when they are used for fraudulent or illegal purposes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Judgment creditors were not entitled to piercing of LLC's corporate veil.

Title: Latham v. Burgher
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: In the context of piercing the corporate veil, actual fraud is not equivalent to the tort of fraud; instead, in that context, actual fraud involves dishonesty of purpose or intent to deceive.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence was sufficient to conclude roofing company owner was roofing company's alter ego.

Title: In re Ryan
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Texas, Fort Worth Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, a shareholder may not be liable to the corporation or its obligees with respect to any contractual obligation or any matter relating to or arising from the obligation on the basis that the shareholder is or was the alter ego of the corporation or on the basis of actual or constructive fraud, sham to perpetrate fraud, or other similar theory. V.T.C.A., Business Organizations Code § 21.223(a)(2).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Homeowners failed to establish alter ego as basis for piercing corporate veil and holding debtor personally liable for debts.

Title: In re Ryan
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Texas, Fort Worth Division.
Headnote: Under subsection (b) of the section of the Texas Business Organizations Code governing limitation of liability for obligations, the limitation on a shareholder's liability does not protect the shareholder if the obligee demonstrates the shareholder caused the corporation to be used for the purpose of perpetrating, and did perpetrate, an actual fraud on the obligee primarily for the direct personal benefit of the shareholder; in other words, subsection (b) establishes the basis on which an obligee may pierce the corporate veil. V.T.C.A., Business Organizations Code § 21.223(a, b).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Homeowners failed to establish alter ego as basis for piercing corporate veil and holding debtor personally liable for debts.

Title: In re Ryan
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Texas, Fort Worth Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, the sham to perpetrate fraud doctrine prevents the use of the corporate entity as a cloak for fraud or illegality to work an injustice. V.T.C.A., Business Organizations Code § 21.223.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Homeowners failed to establish alter ego as basis for piercing corporate veil and holding debtor personally liable for debts.

Title: In re Ryan

Title: In re Ryan

Title: In re Ryan

Title: Ottens v. McNeil

Title: Phillips v. United Heritage Corp.

Title: Phillips v. United Heritage Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Waco.
Headnote: The plain and intended meaning of "affiliate" under statute requiring finding of actual fraud to pierce corporate veil when contractual obligation is involve, stating that any affiliate of a corporation shall be under no obligation to the corporation or its obligees, encompasses any individual who is affiliated with: (1) a shareholder of the corporation; (2) a beneficial owner or subscriber of shares of the corporation; or (3) simply the corporation itself in some capacity. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21(A) (Expired).

Title: In re Smith

Title: In re Smith

Title: In re Jarvar
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Montana.
Headnote: Montana courts consider two factors in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil: (1) the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must show that the corporation is the alter ego of the individual, and (2) there must be a showing that the corporate entity was used as a subterfuge to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, or perpetrate fraud.

Title: Antonio v. Security Services of America, LLC

Headnote: Under Maryland law, the protection afforded to corporate "entity" will only be disregarded when it is necessary to prevent fraud or to enforce a paramount equity.

Title: Naples v. Keystone Bldg. and Development Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: The instrumentality rule, as basis for piercing the corporate veil, requires, in any case but an express agency, proof of three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) that such control was used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty or a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of the plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) that the control and breach of duty proximately caused the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Vendor and Purchaser. Amount of damages awarded to new home purchasers was clearly erroneous.

Title: Naples v. Keystone Bldg. and Development Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Ordinarily the corporate veil is pierced only under exceptional circumstances, for example, where the corporation is a mere shell, serving no legitimate purpose, and is used primarily as an intermediary to perpetuate fraud or promote injustice.

Headnote: The improper use of the corporate form is the key to the inquiry regarding piercing of the corporate veil, as courts will disregard legal fictions, including that of a separate corporate entity, when they are used for fraudulent or illegal purposes.

Title: In re Carlson
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Idaho.
Headnote: Under Idaho law, two requirements must be met to disregard the form of the corporate entity and impose personal liability on the shareholder: first, plaintiff must prove a unity of interest and ownership such that separate legal personalities of the corporation and individual no longer exist, and, second, plaintiff must show that, if the acts are treated as those of the corporation, an inequitable result would follow or that it would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.

Title: Bear, Inc. v. Smith
Court: Court of Appeals of Kentucky.
Headnote: Under the alter ego theory for holding the shareholders of a corporation responsible for corporate liabilities, a plaintiff must prove: (1) that the corporation is not only influenced by the owners, but also that there is such unity of ownership and interest that their separateness has ceased; and (2) that the facts are such that treatment of the corporation as a separate entity would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.

Title: In re England Motor Co.

Headnote: Under Mississippi law, courts will not pierce the veil of a corporate entity unless the party seeking to treat the entities as a single enterprise demonstrates: (1) some frustration of expectations regarding the party to whom he looked for performance, (2) the flagrant disregard of corporate formalities by the principals of the corporation, and (3) some indication of fraud or other equivalent malfeasance by the corporate principals.

Title: Spagnola v. Chubb Corp.

Headnote: To establish that shielding a shareholder from liability for a corporation's actions would result in injustice or fundamental unfairness, as required to properly plead alter-ego liability under Minnesota or Indiana law, proof of strict common law fraud is not required, but, rather, evidence that the corporate entity has been operated as a constructive fraud or in an unjust manner must be presented.

Title: Reinhart v. Boeck

Headnote: Corporate entities do not commit fraud, but corporate officers, agents, and employees do; hence, while courts are generally reluctant to disregard the corporate identity, they will do so to protect third parties from fraud or injustice when transacting business with a corporate entity.

Title: In re BH S & B Holdings LLC

Title: In re BH S & B Holdings LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, with respect to the second factor required to pierce the corporate veil, namely, a showing of unfairness or injustice, the fraud or similar injustice must be found in the defendants' use of the corporate form; in other words, the underlying cause of action, at least by itself, does not supply the necessary fraud or injustice, as to hold otherwise would render the fraud or injustice element meaningless and would sanction bootstrapping.

Title: JNS Aviation, Inc. v. Nick Corp.

Title: JNS Aviation, Inc. v. Nick Corp.

Title: McCallum Family L.L.C. v. Winger
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Div. VII.
Headnote: To determine whether it is appropriate to pierce the corporate veil, a court must make a three-part inquiry: first, the court must determine whether the corporate entity is the "alter ego" of the person or entity in issue; second, the court must determine whether justice requires recognizing the substance of the relationship between the person or entity sought to be held liable and the corporation over the form because the corporate fiction was used to perpetrate a fraud or defeat a rightful claim; and third, the court must consider whether an equitable result will be achieved by disregarding the corporate form and holding a shareholder or other insider personally liable for the acts of the business entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. The burden of proof in an action to pierce the corporate veil is by a preponderance of the evidence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: McCallum Family L.L.C. v. Winger
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Div. VII.
Headnote: The second prong of the veil-piercing inquiry, that the court must determine whether justice requires recognizing the substance of the relationship between the person or entity sought to be held liable and the corporation over the form because the corporate fiction was used to perpetrate a fraud or defeat a rightful claim, reflects a recognition that the corporate veil may be pierced only when the corporate form was used to shield a dominant shareholder's improprieties.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. The burden of proof in an action to pierce the corporate veil is by a preponderance of the evidence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: McCallum Family L.L.C. v. Winger
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Div. VII.
Headnote: Second prong of the test on piercing the corporate veil, under which a plaintiff may show either fraud or that the corporate form was abused to defeat the rightful claims of creditors, has no additional requirement to prove any conduct specifically directed at the plaintiff-creditor; however, the creditor seeking to pierce the veil must show an effect on its lawful rights as a creditor resulting from abuse of the corporate form.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. The burden of proof in an action to pierce the corporate veil is by a preponderance of the evidence.

Title: GEM Advisors, Inc. v. Corporacion Sidenor, S.A.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, a court may pierce the corporate veil where (1) the owner exercised complete domination over the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue, and (2) such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce the veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Subsidiary acted as corporation's agent for purposes of personal jurisdiction over corporation in breach of contract action.

Title: GEM Advisors, Inc. v. Corporacion Sidenor, S.A.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, fraud or wrong causing injury required to pierce the corporate veil can be satisfied by showing a breach of a legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Subsidiary acted as corporation's agent for purposes of personal jurisdiction over corporation in breach of contract action.

Title: U.S. v. Stephens
Court: United States District Court, D. Montana, Billings Division.
Headnote: Under Montana law, courts may pierce the corporate veil if (1) the corporation is the alter ego of the individual and (2) the corporate entity was used as a subterfuge to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, or perpetrate fraud.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Collection. United States could reach assets of taxpayer's corporations to recover unpaid tax assessments for personal income tax.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Washington Mut., Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: When the corporate form has been used to defraud third parties, the corporate form may be disregarded to avoid injustice, but the fraud must relate to the corporate form itself.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Mortgages and Deeds of Trust. Mortgagor's complaint did not state plausible claim that holding company was liable for misconduct in servicing mortgage.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Longhi v. Mazzoni
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: As a general rule, Indiana courts are reluctant to disregard corporate identity and do so only to protect third parties from fraud or injustice when transacting business with a corporate entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil and treble damages were warranted where manager of development company used down payment on home as investment capital.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: North American Clearing, Inc. v. Brokerage Computer Systems, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Orlando Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, piercing corporate veil requires two elements: (1) the corporation is in actuality the alter ego of the stockholders, and (2) it was organized or after organization was employed by the stockholders for fraudulent or misleading purposes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Shareholder's alleged conduct in causing licensee to decompile software did not entitle licensor to piercing of corporate veil.

Title: North American Clearing, Inc. v. Brokerage Computer Systems, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Orlando Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, shareholder's conduct involving corporation as alleged alter ego may be deemed improper where the corporation was employed for fraudulent or misleading purposes, was organized or used to mislead creditors or to perpetrate a fraud upon them, or to evade existing personal liability.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Shareholder's alleged conduct in causing licensee to decompile software did not entitle licensor to piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Khan v. Douglas Machine & Tool Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, corporate entities are presumed to be distinct and veil piercing is only appropriate when (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Subordination agreement prevented debenture holder from bringing an action to enforce the debenture.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: McAnaney v. Astoria Financial Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York., E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, two elements must be shown in order to pierce the corporate veil: (1) that the owner exercised complete dominion over the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce the veil.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - States. Mortgagors' claim against mortgagees under New York Real Property Law was preempted by Home Owners' Loan Act.

Title: In re Hecker
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, disregard of the corporate entity theories is equitable in nature, and generally is not available, absent fraud.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Debtor could not reverse-pierce corporate veil to claim Minnesota homestead exemption in property owned by LLC.

Title: Shkolnik v. Krutoy
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: While the law permits the incorporation of a business for the very purpose of escaping personal liability, equity will intervene to pierce the corporate veil and permit the imposition of personal liability in order to avoid fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Defendants failed to make prima facie showing of entitlement to judgment as a matter of law on breach of contract claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Shkolnik v. Krutoy
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: A party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must show that the owners of the corporation exercised complete domination over it in the transaction at issue, and that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff under circumstances that constitute an abuse of the privilege of doing business in the corporate form.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Defendants failed to make prima facie showing of entitlement to judgment as a matter of law on breach of contract claims.

Title: In re Saba Enterprises, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, courts may pierce the corporate veil either in the event of a fraud or where the corporation has been so dominated by an individual or corporate parent that the subsidiary is relegated to the status of a mere shell, instrumentality, or alter ego.

Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Generally, under Colorado law, if adherence to the corporate fiction would promote injustice, protect fraud, defeat a legitimate claim, or defend crime, the invocation of equitable principles for the imposition of personal liability through piercing of the corporate veil may occur.

Headnote: Under Texas law, fraud is essential element of alter ego finding in contract case.

Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Texas, Austin Division.
Headnote: Sham to perpetrate a fraud doctrine is typically applied by Texas courts when controlling entity siphons off revenue and sells off much of the other entity's assets, or does other acts to hinder on-going business and ability of corporation to pay its debts.

Title: In re SMTC Mfg. of Texas
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Texas, Austin Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, focus of sham to perpetrate a fraud doctrine is not on relationship between corporation and its owners, but on injustice or unfairness to claimant caused by corporation and its owners.
